title: Ted Cruz Says Donald Trump Has Been Deceiving Voters on Immigration
description: SAN ANTONIO  On the eve of what could be the most important day of his candidacy, Senator Ted Cruz on Monday took furious aim at Donald J. Trumps signature issue  his hard-line immigration positions  suggesting that Mr. Trump was insulting the intelligence of his supporters.

title: Review: Christine Andreass Nostalgic Turn in Cafe Society
description: The past usually looks prettier than the present, especially when its set to music. And in her new show, Caf Society, at Feinsteins at 54 Below, Christine Andreas looks back longingly to the days before television usurped the evening hours and fashionable New Yorkers flocked to nightclubs.

title: Gawker and Union Reach Agreement on Contract
description: Gawker Media and the union that represents its employees announced on Monday that they had reached an agreement on a labor contract, the first designed and negotiated specifically for a digital media company.

title: Autonomous Google Car Hits Public Bus During Test Drive
description: A self-driving car being tested by Google struck a public bus on a city street in Mountain View, Calif. The tech companys vehicles have been involved in more than a dozen minor accidents, but this fender-bender may represent the first time that a Google car has caused an accident. A report from Google on the Feb. 14 episode was posted online Monday by Californias Department of Motor Vehicles. Googles car was moving at less than two miles an hour and the bus at 15 m.p.h. No one was injured. The report does not address fault, but Google wrote that its car was trying to get around some sandbags when its left front struck the right side of the bus. Google did not have immediate comment. (AP)

title: Supreme Court Looks at Recusals in Capital Trials
description: WASHINGTON  There was something like a consensus at the Supreme Court on Monday that it was not a good idea for a judge to hear a death penalty case he had worked on as a district attorney. But the justices seemed divided over how to fashion a constitutional rule that would bar such conduct yet not require judges to recuse themselves whenever they had had a glancing encounter with the matter under review.

title: Should a Judge Rule on His Own Case?
description: It would be hard to imagine a more glaring judicial conflict of interest than the one the Supreme Court considered in a case out of Pennsylvania on Monday.

title: Bernie Sanders Promises to Keep Pressing the Campaign
description: BOSTON  Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont vowed on Monday night that no matter the outcome of the Super Tuesday races, his campaign would continue to rally voters against a political establishment that is largely backing his rival, Hillary Clinton.

title: 2002 Letter on Eavesdropping Is Made Public
description: The Obama administration on Monday made public a previously classified letter from 2002 about the Bush administrations secret program that allowed the National Security Agency to eavesdrop on Americans international communications without court orders. The letter, written by John Yoo, then a top lawyer in the Justice Departments Office of Legal Counsel, adds to the historical record of the surveillance and bulk data collection program known as Stellarwind. It explained to Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, then the newly installed chief judge of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, why the Justice Department had blessed the program as lawful even though, as Mr. Yoo acknowledged, that it probably clashed with wiretapping laws.

title: Spotlight Oscar Warms Boston Globe, and Journalism
description: Less than two months ago, Boston Globe reporters and editors were delivering thousands of copies of their own newspaper, mollifying subscribers who were upset by sporadic delivery service.

title: When the Kitchen Is Also a Bedroom: Overcrowding Worsens in New York
description: Rafaels housing situation is an exercise in tolerance and creative space management. He lives with four other people in an overstuffed apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens, that measures less than 500 square feet.

title: Ethics Group Urges Inquiry of Mortgage Banking Lobbyist Who Led F.H.A.
description: A nonprofit watchdog group on Monday called for an investigation of David H. Stevens, chief executive of the Mortgage Bankers Association, arguing that he may have violated ethics laws relating to his previous position as commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Testing for Joy and Grit? Schools Nationwide Push to Measure Students Emotional Skills
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The fifth graders in Jade Cooneys classroom compete against a kitchen timer during lessons to see how long they can sustain good behavior  raising hands, disagreeing respectfully and looking one another in the eye  without losing time to insults or side conversations.

title: Evictions Are Down by 18%; New York City Cites Increased Legal Services
description: Evictions in New York City dropped last year to their lowest level in a decade, as the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio bolstered efforts to prevent more New Yorkers from becoming homeless.

title: G.O.P. Legislators Face New Pressure to Decide: Can They Get Behind Trump?
description: WASHINGTON  The unraveling of a party hierarchy increasingly in the shadow of Donald J. Trump has shifted to Capitol Hill, where Republican members of Congress are beginning to split between those who could accept, even embrace, the billionaire as their nominee and those who have vowed, Never Trump.

title: Brexit Vote and Donald Trumps Surge Reflect Discontent
description: Britain may be on the cusp of having its own Donald Trump moment.

title: After Gains Against ISIS, Pentagon Focuses on Mosul
description: WASHINGTON  Recent gains against the Islamic State in eastern Syria have helped sever critical supply lines to Iraq and set the stage for what will be the biggest fight yet against the Sunni militancy, the battle to retake Mosul, Pentagon officials said on Monday.

title: The Approach to Super Tuesday
description: Photographs from the presidential campaign trail on Monday.

title: Slights, Gags and Vitriol as Rivals Target Donald Trump
description: Join us for live updates and analysis of Super Tuesday.

title: Davis Cup Controversy Proves Not All Records Age Gracefully
description: For years, two tennis players with little in common other than their love for the sport held records that seemed unlikely to be broken.

title: A Look Back at a Decade of Oscar Telecasts
description: The viewership for the Oscar telecast has generally fallen in recent years. The ratings have not come near the numbers in 1998, when Titanic won big.

title: Donald Trumps Message Resonates With White Supremacists
description: Join us for live updates and analysis of Super Tuesday.

title: Utilities Cautioned About Potential for a Cyberattack
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has warned the nations power companies, water suppliers and transportation networks that sophisticated cyberattack techniques used to bring down part of Ukraines power grid two months ago could easily be turned on them.

title: Syria: United Nations Says Food Aid Will Be Restored
description: The United Nations announcedon Mondaythat it would fully restore all food aid to hundreds of thousands of war-ravaged Syrians that had been cut by funding shortfalls. In astatement, the World Food Program, the main United Nations anti-hunger agency, said $675 million pledged at a London donor conference in February would allow it to fully reinstate the reduced aid to Syrian refugees in Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq and Egypt for the rest of 2016. The money will also allow the agency to restore cutbacks imposed on internally displaced Syrians, at least until October. Most of the new money was provided by Germany, the statement said. The World Food Program, a pillar of aid to Syrian civilians in the five-year-old war, was forced to make cuts last year because its budget was drastically underfunded.

title: Email About North Korea on Hillary Clintons Server
description: The State Department released this email that was sent to Hillary Clinton's private computer server from one of her top aides while she was secretary of state. The email, now classified, is at the center of a dispute over the handling of government data on her server.

title: Email Directing Follow-Up on Secure Line
description: An email sent to Hillary Clinton while she was secretary of state from one of her top aides, Huma Abedin, encouraged her to follow up on an issue concerning North Korea using a secure line, showing at least some intent on the part of her staff to follow classification protocols.

title: Last Batch of Hillary Clintons Emails Is Released
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department on Monday released the last set of emails from the 30,000 messages on Hillary Clintons private computer server, including an email about North Korea that remains a point of dispute between the department and one of the nations spy agencies over the secrecy of information that passed through the server.

title: Winners of Pictures of the Year International
description: With a nod to the importance of local coverage, this years Pictures of the Year International contest chose a young Texas photographer as the Newspaper Photographer of the Year.

title: Winners of Pictures of the Year International
description: In her first year out of college, Carolyn Van Houten of The San Antonio Express-News has been named Newspaper Photographer of the Year in the Pictures of the Year International contest. She joined the papers staff in January of last year after graduating from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where she was named College Photographer of the Year in a separate national competition associated with POYi.

title: Developing a Little Sleight of Hand Behind the Plate
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Brian McCann was a promising catching prospect for the Atlanta Braves, they appreciated his powerful bat, his intuitiveness in calling a game, his strong arm and quiet hands behind the plate. Putting a value on his bat was straightforward. The logic of pitch sequencing could be deconstructed. His arm strength could be quantified with a stopwatch.

title: Inside the Clinton Teams Plan to Defeat Donald Trump
description: In the days after Donald J. Trump vanquished his Republican rivals in South Carolina and Nevada, prominent Democrats supporting Hillary Clinton arranged a series of meetings and conference calls to tackle a question many never thought they would ask: How do we defeat Mr. Trump in a general election?

title: Claude Parent, Visionary Architect of the Oblique, Dies at 93
description: Claude Parent, the French architectural visionary who in the 1950s broke with his traditional Beaux-Arts training and then orthodox Modernism to take a radical course, designing buildings on the oblique instead of the vertical and horizontal, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 93.

title: Review: In The Wildness, Defenses Against Adulthood
description: Wild is not quite the word for The Wildness. This tuneful, thin-skinned production, which opened on Monday night at Ars Nova with the subtitle Sky-Ponys Rock Fairy Tale, often feels as cozy as the giant patchwork quilt that canopies its runway of a set.

title: 1950 Bette Davis Film
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Fasten your seat belts. Its going to be a bumpy puzzle.

title: Relics of the Space Age
description: Abandoned in Place, a new book of photographs by Roland Miller, finds haunting beauty in derelict launch pads, rusting towers and other detritus of the American space race.

title: Trial Opens for Air Force Veteran Accused of Trying to Join ISIS
description: While working as an American contractor across the Middle East, Tairod Pugh earned a reputation for his abilities as an airplane mechanic and for his extremist views.

title: Alice Arlen, Screenwriter and Collaborator With Nora Ephron, Dies at 75
description: Alice Arlen, a screenwriter who collaborated with Nora Ephron on the 1983 Mike Nichols film Silkwood, the story of a lab worker killed in a suspicious car crash en route to meet a reporter to expose what she considered life-threatening dangers at a nuclear plant, died on Monday evening at her home in Manhattan. She was 75.

title: Blindspot Season 1, Episode 11: Can You Land This Plane?
description: Blindspot was one of NBCs success stories in the first half of the TV season, and on Monday night it came back after its winter hiatus as fast-paced and preposterous and addictive as ever. It was an hour that featured a weird bit of casting, apparent confirmation that the memory-wiped and heavily tattooed Jane is indeed Taylor Shaw, and more evidence that Ashley Johnsons forensic-tech character, Patterson, is stealing this series.

title: Better Call Saul Recap: Season 2, Episode 3: Lone Star State of Mind
description: Say this for Mondays episode: It ends with cliffhangers.

title: New Jersey Man Charged in Hit-and-Run Death of New York City Officer
description: A Linden, N.J., man was charged on Monday in the hit-and-run death of an off-duty New York City police officer the day before, the New Jersey State Police said.

title: Classified 2002 Letter on N.S.A. Eavesdropping Is Made Public
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday made public a previously classified letter from 2002 about the Bush administrations secret program that allowed the National Security Agency to eavesdrop on Americans international communications without court orders.

title: Human Skeleton Found in Brooklyn Home Left Vacant for Years
description: Investigators are trying to determine the identity of a human skeleton found by a Brooklyn home buyer on Monday in a building believed to have been vacant for about 10 years, the police said.

title: Mount St. Marys President Quits After Firings Seen as Retaliatory
description: A Maryland university president resigned on Monday, weeks after a furor erupted on campus over faculty firings and a student newspaper article that quoted the president as comparing struggling freshmen to bunnies that should be drowned or shot.

title: Knicks Raise Their Game, on Twitter
description: The Knicks did not play Monday, which was just as well, since they have lost 14 of 17 games. But they continue to tweet.

title: A Guide to the Voting on Super Tuesday
description: Which states are voting and how many delegates are at stake.

title: Waste in Cancer Drugs Costs $3 Billion a Year, a Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  The federal Medicare program and private health insurers waste nearly $3 billion every year buying cancer medicines that are thrown out because many drug makers distribute the drugs only in vials that hold too much for most patients, a group of cancer researchers has found.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | convex
description: convex  \spek-trm\  adjective

title: In the Temples of Hoosier Hardwood
description: Basketball is nearly sacred in Indiana, where two photographers set out to document scores of gyms during events like basketball games and graduations.

title: Nine Authors, Playwrights Win $150,000 Windham-Campbell Prizes
description: The Windham-Campbell Prizes on Tuesday announced its annual list of nine winners. Each of the recipients receives $150,000 for accomplishments in the worlds of literature and theater.

title: Fake New York Times Article Claims Elizabeth Warren Endorsed Bernie Sanders
description: A webpage that masqueraded as a New York Times article and claimed that Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts had endorsed Bernie Sanders for president circulated widely on social media on Monday.

title: Devils Deal Lee Stempniak Amid Final Whirl of Trades
description: The Devils traded their leading scorer, Lee Stempniak, to the Boston Bruins on Monday; swapped forwards with the Montreal Canadiens; and traded defenseman Eric Gelinas to the Colorado Avalanche.

title: Review: Adele Arrives in an Arena at Last
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  Adele is not daunted by arenas anymore. On Monday night she started a world tour here at the SSE Arena Belfast, announcing early on, This is my first time in an arena, ever, playing to my own fans. Moments later, she added that anxiety before the concert had caused her to have severe bowel movements.

title: What to Watch Tuesday
description: Viceland, the new cable channel from the nonconformist Vice Media, moves into the slot once occupied by H2 and toward subjects typically at home on Travel Channel, Bravo and MTV. Alicia Vikander, a newly anointed Oscar recipient for The Danish Girl, portrays the British pacifist Vera Brittain in Testament of Youth. And the networks report on Super Tuesday.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Bonjour, Day 1
description: The first day of March is also the first day of shows for Paris Fashion Week, the final leg of the seasons four-city marathon. And it eases everyone gently into what is usually the most jam-packed period.

title: In the Temples of Indiana High School Basketball
description: Lets say you happen to be in Indiana and you run across a basketball court  and lets just stop right there. You go to Indiana, its hard to imagine you wont run across a basketball court. Theyre like Starbucks there, only it may be easier to get a seat at Starbucks.

title: Corrections: March 1, 2016
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Ms. Eisenstein, one question.

title: What Wouldnt Jesus Do?
description: AMONG the most inexplicable developments in this bizarre political year is that Donald Trump is the candidate of choice of many evangelical Christians.

title: The Movement Mentality
description: It feels like people clumped themselves into intellectual movements more 30 years ago than they do today. There were paleoconservatives and neoconservatives. There were modernists and postmodernists; liberals, realists, and neoliberals; communitarians and liberation theologians; Jungians and Freudians; Straussians and deconstructionists; feminists and post-feminists; Marxists and democratic socialists. Maybe there were even some transcendentalists, existentialists, pragmatists, agrarians and Gnostics floating around.

title: Texas Voters Are Mellower Than the Candidates
description: HOUSTON  In Texas, by state law, schoolchildren start the day saying two pledges of allegiance. The second one goes, Honor the Texas flag; I pledge allegiance to thee, Texas, one state under God, one and indivisible.

title: Iran Election Boosts President Rouhani
description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran was quick to boast about returns showing that his reformist and moderate supporters had done well in voting for Irans new Parliament and influential clerical council. Kudos to the history-making nation of Iran. Lets open a new chapter based on domestic talents & global opportunities, he wrote on social media on Monday.

title: Big-Donor Money Has Not Worked in the 2016 Campaign. Yet.
description: No matter who comes out on top on Super Tuesday, this round of presidential primaries has been turning conventional notions about campaign finance upside down. For the time being.

title: Something Funny Happened on the Way to the Election
description: Gail Collins: Arthur, do you remember that old musical number, Another Opnin, Another Show? Here we are at Super Tuesday! Voters are dancing across the stage and Donald Trump is lurking in the wings. What do you think?

title: Feed Your Dog, Feed Your Soul
description: Of all the patients I have seen in my 40 years as a psychoanalyst, Daniel was the strangest. He was the most inaccessible, inwardly tormented and infuriating man I have ever known, and yet he stayed in therapy with me for over a decade, calling faithfully every week  he insisted that his work schedule precluded coming in person  even though he spent many of those sessions in silence or addressed me as if I were inanimate. He drove me crazy, he haunted me and he moved me, sometimes all in the same session.

title: Bernie Sanders Raised Over $42 Million in February, Campaign Says
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised more than $42 million during February, his campaign said on Tuesday.

title: Glencores Big Loss Reflects Hard Times for Mining Companies
description: LONDON  Glencore, the mining and energy giant whose fortunes over the last year have been hit particularly hard by the global price slump in raw materials, said on Tuesday that it lost $5 billion in 2015.

title: Barclays, Posting Loss, Plans to Reduce Business in Africa
description: LONDON  The British bank Barclays said on Tuesday that it planned to cut its stake in its African business, slash its dividend and focus its strategy around two divisions: its British consumer bank and its corporate and investment bank.

title: Chinese Court Upholds Life Sentence for Top Aide to Bo Xilai
description: BEIJING  A court in northeastern China has said that a senior aide to Bo Xilai, an imprisoned former high-ranking Communist Party official, must serve a life sentence in prison for corruption.

title: News Qs | Scott Kellys Year in Space
description: The following lesson activities are based on the article Scott Kellys Year in Space.

title: Making Black Voices Matter
The Decorous Demise of the Establishment
description: We have a multicar pileup on Establishment Lane, with fatalities reported. The most mangled vehicle belongs to the defunct presidential campaign of John Ellis (Jeb) Bush.

title: Do You Really Need Rental Car Insurance? 8 Things to Know
description: With every car rental transaction comes the slightly uncomfortable moment when the agent behind the counter tries to foist the companys insurance on you. When this happened to me at Hertz at the Hilo International Airport in Hawaii a few weeks ago, I did what I always do: I firmly and politely said no, thank you.

title: Obama and G.O.P. Senators Meet on Filling Scalias Seat, to No Avail
description: WASHINGTON  The two Republican senators sat together on one couch, while the Democratic senators sat a few feet away on another, but the gap between them in Tuesdays meeting with President Obama in the Oval Office could hardly have been bigger.

title: The Fashion Game at the N.B.A. All-Star Game
description: When the N.B.A. All-Star Game took place in Toronto in February, it not only gave Canada a chance to show off its basketball chops, but it also gave its top players a chance to strut.

title: How to Stay Sane on a Business Trip
description: A specific condition afflicts business travelers: Call it hotel gloom, an amorphous melancholy that seems to thrive in the perfectly serviceable hotel rooms of the $200-a-night-and-under variety. Al Jackson has experienced it many times.

title: New Weapon in Day Laborers Fight Against Wage Theft: A Smartphone App
description: Just past sunrise on 69th Street, near a No. 7 subway stop in Queens, men in backpacks and work boots gather in groups, many on their cellphones.

description: Should prisoners be given the opportunity to get an education?

title: To Circumcise or Not to Circumcise: A New Fathers Question
description: We never gave much thought to circumcision. Our son was a surviving twin born at 27 weeks gestation. He spent the first 76 days of his life in the newborn intensive care unit at Prentice Womens Hospital in Chicago. Because he was fighting for his life, there were more pressing matters to consider than the shape of his penis.

title: Dark Territory: The Secret History of Cyber War, by Fred Kaplan
description: If history were taught in the form of stories, it would never be forgotten, Rudyard Kipling said. Dark Territory takes this approach in trying to tell what it calls in its subtitle The Secret History of Cyber War.

title: All the Single Ladies, by Rebecca Traister
description: Throughout Americas history, the start of adult life for women  whatever else it might have been destined to include  had been typically marked by marriage, Rebecca Traister writes in her new book, All the Single Ladies: Unmarried Women and the Rise of an Independent Nation. Since the late 19th century, the median age of first marriage for women had fluctuated between 20 and 22. This had been the shape, pattern and definition of female life.

title: Have We Been Playing Gershwin Wrong for 70 Years?
description: It is one of the most famous pieces of American music  but for 70 years orchestras may have been playing one of its best-known effects wrong.

title: Owner of N.Y.S.E. Confirms Interest in London Stock Exchange
description: LONDON  The IntercontinentalExchange, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange, said on Tuesday that it was considering making a competing offer for the London Stock Exchange Group.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Super Tuesday, iPhone, Zika Virus
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Morning Agenda: Barclays to Sell Unit in Africa
description: BARCLAYS TO SELL UNIT IN AFRICA | Barclays plans to sell down its stake in its African business, which was one of four pillars of Barclays strategy until last year, when Antony Jenkins was ousted from his job as chief executive,Chad Bray reports in DealBook.

title: How New Hampshire Used the Wrong Math and Gave One of Rubios Delegates to Trump
description: After the polls closed in New Hampshire on Feb. 9, the Republican primary had a clear winner: Donald J. Trump. It took nearly two weeks for the state to award its 23 delegates, and in the end it gave Mr. Trump 11, John Kasich four, Ted Cruz and Jeb Bush three each and Marco Rubio two. But theres a small problem: It looks as if New Hampshire gave Mr. Trump a delegate that actually belongs to Mr. Rubio.

title: Koch-Linked Group Releases Ad Backing G.O.P. Candidate for Harry Reids Seat
description: The Koch network is unleashing its first political ad of 2016, right in Senator Harry Reids backyard.

title: New York Today: Training to Be Trump
description: Updated, 7:10 a.m.

title: Q. and A.: Zhang Fan on Chinese Parachute Kids in the U.S.
description: In his Southern California prison, Zhang Xinlei, 19, from the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen, is finally acquiring the education he missed in his American high schools. Now that he is actually mixing with Americans, his father says, his English is improving rapidly.

title: Super Tuesday Extends to Senate Races as Well
description: Super Tuesday isnt just for presidential campaigns: It is also the years first set of congressional primaries. And some senior Republican lawmakers are trying to make sure they are not the next Eric Cantor or Richard G. Lugar, established Capitol Hill powers knocked off from the right in a preliminary round.

title: Hamas Commander, Accused of Theft and Gay Sex, Is Killed by His Own
description: GAZA CITY  The death of Mahmoud Ishtiwi had all the trappings of a telenovela: sex, torture and embezzlement in Gazas most venerated and secretive institution, the armed wing of Hamas.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start the day.

title: The Challenge of Taming Air Turbulence
description: He had taken a few hard hits as a quarterback for the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League.

title: In Singapore, Craft Beer Where Youd Least Expect It
description: Silhouetted against pastel-colored shophouses in the historic Chinatown district of Singapore, Daniel Goh leaned forward at a lime-green table on the second floor of the Chinatown Complex to take a break from his animated critique of the city-states rapidly developing craft beer scene. The thing most people dont know, he said, is that people used to come here to die.

title: The Plot to Take Down a Fox News Analyst
description: Kent Clizbe, a 55-year-old former C.I.A. officer and intelligence contractor, has cultivated a diverse set of interests in his later years. He loves bird watching and participates in his local Christmas Bird Count, an informal census organized by the Audubon Society. He has a patent on a device, the TimeOff, that prevents unattended-stove fires. But Clizbes true motivating force  a holdover, perhaps, from his decade with the agency  is an unrelenting compulsion to get to the bottom of things. He vets every person he meets, interrogating every fact presented to him. This perpetual need to turn everything inside out is the defining trait of Clizbes personality, and he remains faithful to it, even when it incurs him great personal expense.

title: In a Harvard Scholars 18th-Century History, Glimpses of Modern China
description: BEIJING  How does an autocratic ruler trample on the law? How does a bureaucracy manipulate the ruler? How does a government accommodate people of unconventional lifestyles and beliefs? The Harvard historian Philip A. Kuhn cited these as questions worth exploring in his preface to the Chinese translation of a book he wrote about 18th-century China. His death last month at the age of 82 has revived these questions for those who see striking parallels with contemporary politics.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Feb. 23-29, 2016
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Britain Drops Case Against Last Suspect in 1998 Omagh Bombing
description: DUBLIN  The case against the remaining suspect facing criminal charges in the killing of 29 people in a bombing in Omagh in 1998, the deadliest attack during three decades of bloody conflict in Northern Ireland, collapsed on Tuesday after the state prosecutor unexpectedly dropped the matter.

title: Why Cant the G.O.P. Stop Trump?

title: Europe Stalls
description: Ive been saying for a while that Europe and the US are locked in an intense competition, to see which of these huge, powerful, rich, sophisticated societies could screw up most. For a long time Europe seemed to be winning that competition, but recently the deep bench GOP has given America a big boost.

title: Super Tuesday: From Past to Present
description: The idea of Super Tuesday is a relatively recent introduction into presidential politics. The first one was in 1984, when President Reagan was the uncontested Republican candidate. It has changed since.

title: 1941: Nazi Troops Move Into Bulgaria
description: SOFIA  On this first day of March, Fuehrer Adolf Hitlers lucky month, a step was taken which will provide new military enterprises for his army. In its defense of the Reich, this mighty fighting organism has reached the Bulgarian capital, and already it throws its shadow over Greece. Soldiers in the gray-green uniforms of the German Army arrived in Sofia this afternoon.

title: Polls Open for Super Tuesday Voting
description: Voters in 12 states are going to the polls as Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton look to extend their delegate leads.

title: Raw Tensions Over Race Fester in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  It would be hard to find a land so steeped in the torments and conflicts of race as South Africa. Apartheids ghosts still stalk the land, conjuring dire warnings about its very fabric. For those who yearned for a rainbow nation, it was not supposed to be this way.

description: WASHINGTON  American drones were devastating the upper ranks of Al Qaeda, his men were killing suspected spies, and Osama bin Laden wondered: Could an Iranian dentist have planted a tracking device in his wifes tooth?

title: Find an Ice Flower Before It Melts
description: After unseasonably warm weather, some parts of the country are expected to be blasted by winter storms over the coming weeks. There may be a tiny, fleeting bright side for those who live in places where something known as frostweed grows: ice flowers.

title: Russian Foreign Minister Calls for New Chemical Weapons Accord
description: GENEVA  Russias foreign minister called on Tuesday for negotiations on a new international treaty to counter the extremely urgent threat of chemical warfare by terrorists, as exemplified by attacks by Islamic State forces in Syria and Iraq last year.

title: Israeli Soldiers Get Lost Using Waze App, and Clashes Follow
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Two Israeli soldiers led astray by their smartphone navigation app accidentally wandered into an unruly area of the West Bank, provoking clashes and a gun battle that left a Palestinian man dead.

title: Super Tuesday: Analysis
With G.E. Leaving Fairfield, a Developer Looks to Step In
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  General Electrics announcement in January that it will abandon its suburban headquarters here after more than 40 years sent a chill through Albert J. Kleban, the 85-year-old chairman of Kleban Properties, the largest commercial property owner in town.

title: Questions for The Timess Former Jerusalem Bureau Chief?
description: Jodi Rudoren, in her nearly four years as Jerusalem bureau chief, inspired more reader email than any correspondent in history, according to her editors. Heres your chance to ask her anything.

title: Jane the Virgin Season 2, Episode 13: Rafael Gets Shut Down
description: Last weeks episode of Jane the Virgin, ended on such a perfect note for Jane and Michael. They confessed to still being in love with each other, giving Jane another rosy romantic memory to hold dear. Of course, there will always be obstacles in the way of their happy ending  this is a telenovela-inspired sitcom, after all  including, but not limited to, the child that Jane (a virgin, remember) had with another man.

title: A Guide to New York Art Fairs
description: An art fair in New York may seem redundant. After all, the city already has offerings for new art spread among hundreds of galleries in centers like Chelsea, SoHo and Bushwick, in Brooklyn. Whats more, many of them dont charge for admission.

title: To Know Whos Leading in the Voting, Just Ask Google
description: Im always looking for new methods for predicting elections.

title: A New Closeup for a Morgan Library Treasure
description: The Morgan Library & Museums most spectacular piece of bookish bling is now being seen in a new light  quite literally.

title: The Best Shoes of London and Milan Fashion Weeks
description: Armani capped off rainy Milan Fashion Week with these elegant evening flats, reminding us that a little sparkle goes a long way.

title: Panorama Festival Announces Kendrick Lamar and LCD Soundsystem as Headliners
description: Arcade Fire, Kendrick Lamar and LCD Soundsystem will be the headliners for the first Panorama music festival at Randalls Island, from July 22 through July 24, an event from the promoter behind Coachella that has been the subject of months of behind-the-scenes intrigue in the music business.

title: Report on Home Entries and Searches by Police
description: A report from New York's Civilian Complaint Review Board, an independent watchdog agency, analyzed 180 substantiated complaints from 2010 to October 2015 in which people said police officers carried out improper home entries and searches.

title: Bouley
description: A timeless restaurant for romantics and sensualists in TriBeCa.

title: Bouley in TriBeCa Still Goes Its Own Way, Seductively
description: Yes, the apples are still there. Hundreds of them, lining shelf after shelf in Bouleys first room, the small one with the coat closet. Going soft under the skin, ripening, giving up the yeasty cider-mash smell you meet in orchard barns. As far back as 1987, when he opened the original Bouley on the other side of Hudson Street in TriBeCa, David Bouley has wanted that scent inside your head the minute you walked in.

title: 1966: Russian Capsule Reaches Venus
description: MOSCOW  A Soviet space capsule landed today [March 1] on Venus  the first time that an object from the earth has touched down on another planet. The 2,116-pound Venus-3 capsule, its radio dead, smashed into the scorching surface of the earths sister planet after a 106-day flight. The Soviet news agency Tass also disclosed that the capsules companion space probe, Venus-2, passed less than 14,900 miles from Venus on Sunday  the closest fly-past of the planet. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 2, 1966

title: Dismantling Migrant Camp in Calais
description: As evacuation of a migrant camp in France continued, bulldozers ripped apart shelters. Many criticized the move.

title: The Season Without Creative Directors
description: PARIS  In the mythology of fashion month, Paris is considered the crowning jewel; the city where creativity meets history and is blended into vision, which then gets translated into the clothes we all wear. It is the place where all absurdity is forgiven in the name of fashion, and the ridiculous can become the really cool overnight.

title: Europes Border Checks Become Economic Choke Points
description: FREILASSING, Germany  Traffic along one of Europes busiest highways, which used to flow unimpeded, now often backs up for miles at a newly installed checkpoint, where a phalanx of German police officers screens trucks and cars for hidden migrants.

title: Indonesians Flock to Restaurant Where Woman Was Poisoned
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Sitting near the bar at a trendy Jakarta restaurant, Bhian Saraswati, 24, said she was not afraid to eat her roast chicken and mashed potatoes.

title: Pathos of the Reformocons
description: Remember the reformocons (aka reformicons)? For a while they were supposedly a hot trend in Republican politics, right up there with the libertarian moment. Their big hero was Marco Rubio, who said nice things about some of their ideas.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani and Arthur Arbesser in Pictures
description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Monday.

title: Review: The Mariinsky Ballet Offers Works Honoring Its Legends
description: Its clear what someone high up at the Mariinsky Theater must have been thinking when that companys United States tour was being planned. The Mariinsky, repository of ballet classicism, was going to Washington to perform a full-length work; why not send a few dancers, with a marquee name or two, to New York for a simultaneous season, and amortize the costs?

title: 3-Generation Family Trips Gain New Appeal but Can Bare Old Tensions
description: While watching the sunset on the Big Island of Hawaii after a romantic dinner on the beach, Tyler Tepe proposed to his longtime girlfriend, Lindsey Fennen, in July 2007.

title: Sallie Krawcheck Joins Board of Software Start-Up
description: Two former banking stars are joining forces. Sallie Krawcheck, a former top wealth management executive on Wall Street, joined the board of the software start-up Digital Asset Holdings, which is run by Blythe Masters, a former investment banker.

title: Noma Down Under
description: The chef Ren Redzepi and his team are staging a 10-week pop-up restaurant in Australia.

title: In Australia, Noma Forages for Ingredients and Inspiration
description: SYDNEY, Australia  On the menu that comes to the table at the end of the meal, it is described simply as abalone schnitzel and bush condiments.

title: Its About Diversity of Thought
description: Beth Comstock of General Electric and Tony Fadell of Nest discussed the value of diversity in the workplace at The New York Timess New Work Summit.

title: Hotels Offering Deals to Counter Zika Fears
description: Hotels in the Caribbean and Mexico are being hit with room cancellations in the wake of the Zika virus. But these cancellations are not just in Zika-affected areas.

title: Whether Our Foster Child Stays or Goes, He Is Loved
description: Can you tell me again, Mommy? Can you tell me who decides whether I get to stay here?

title: Rolling Stones to Play Free Concert in Cuba
description: It turns out Barack Obama is opening for the Rolling Stones in Cuba.

title: Negative-Yield Bonds for the Nimble Investor
description: In the realm of bonds, negative yields are no bar to positive returns.

title: Lessons From a Season on the Red Carpet: Oscars So Weird
description: The Oscars are behind us and as the season recedes in times rearview mirror, your Carpetbagger (the monikers a riff on the red carpet, by the way) is finding that writing anything else on the awards grows ever more difficult.

title: Ivy League Moves to Eliminate Tackling at Football Practices
description: Ivy League football coaches have decided to take the extraordinary step of eliminating all full-contact hitting from practices during the regular season, the most aggressive measure yet to combat growing concerns about brain trauma and other injuries in the sport.

title: Cryptography Pioneers Win Turing Award
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In 1970, a Stanford artificial intelligence researcher named John McCarthy returned from a conference in Bordeaux, France, where he had presented a paper on the possibility of a Home Information Terminal.

title: Director of Rijksmuseum Is Stepping Down After 8 Years
description: AMSTERDAM  The general director of the Rijksmuseum, Wim Pijbes, announced his resignation on Tuesday, saying that it was time to pursue new opportunities after seeing the museum through a period of expansion and renewal.

title: Chinese Brewer to Buy SABMillers Stake in Snow Beer Maker
description: A state-backed Chinese brewer has agreed to buy out SABMillers stake in the maker of Snow, the worlds best-selling beer, Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Tuesday.

title: Hachette Reaches New Deal With Perseus Books
description: The Hachette Book Group has reached an agreement to buy the Perseus Books Groups publishing business, 18 months after its previous attempt to acquire the company fell through.

title: High Rate of Gun Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Toni Morrison Wins PEN/Saul Bellow Award for Lifetime Achievement
description: PEN America announced on Tuesday that Toni Morrison had won the PEN/Saul Bellow Award for Achievement in American Fiction. The panel of judges for the $25,000 award was composed of Louise Erdrich, who won the award in 2014; Francine Prose; and Dinaw Mengestu. Ms. Morrison adds the award to her Pulitzer Prize (for Beloved, in 1988), Presidential Medal of Freedom (2012), Nobel Prize in Literature (1993) and many other honors.

title: Chris Christie, Fanboy
description: Chris Christie is a big-time fanboy. And never underestimate the thrill of being a fanboy. It can lead to behavior that might seem puzzling at first, or maybe unseemly. But then, the more you think about it, it all makes perfect sense.

title: Peter Grnauer Is Back on the Upper East Side
description: Grnauer Bistro  If you happened to be around in the 1980s, you may remember Peter Grnauer, the Austrian restaurateur who won acclaim at his Vienna 79 and later at his Fledermaus cafes. Now he is back, in the luxuriously wood-paneled room that Upper East Siders knew as Primavera. Hailing from a family that has operated restaurants in Vienna for 70 years, he knows his way around Wiener schnitzels and Sacher tortes. His chef, Thomas Slivovsky, was at the Paulaner restaurant on the Bowery and at Kurt Gutenbrunners Blaue Gans in TriBeCa, and before that at Drei Husaren in Vienna. We opened Vienna 79 when nouvelle cuisine was in fashion, so we went with a modernized, lighter version of Viennese cooking, Mr. Grnauer said. Its pretty much what you will find here. But unlike 30 years ago, there will ample Austrian wines to sample. (Opens Thursday): 1578 First Avenue (East 82nd Street), 212-988-1077, grunauernyc.com.

title: Iraqs Biggest Dam Could Collapse at Any Time, Killing Thousands
description: American officials in Baghdad are warning that a critical dam in northern Iraq may collapse, and that more than a million people could be drowned or left homeless if it gives way.

title: Hogs, Horses and Automobiles: Cespedes Keeps Rolling Along
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The early part of spring training  all drills, no games  can eventually become monotonous. But not at Mets camp, where every day brings another surprise from Yoenis Cespedes, the newly re-signed slugger.

title: The Best Chocolate Youve Never Tasted
description: The worlds most exquisite bars are being made in a garage in Ho Chi Minh City.

title: Listening to Survivors of Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: Britains Looming E.U. Referendum Exposes Tory Squabbles
description: LONDON  For all the high-minded talk of sovereignty and the political urgency of issues like immigration, Britains looming decision on whether to remain a member of the European Union is as much as anything the result of a bitter split within the governing Conservative Party over the countrys relationship with the Continent and its place in the world.

title: Bold Moves Behind Game of Thrones
description: Richard Plepler, chief executive of HBO, discussed the culture of risk-taking he has tried to foster, and how that played out in Game of Thrones, at The New York Timess New Work Summit.

title: HBOs C.E.O. on Streaming Strategies
description: Richard Plepler discussed the companys stand-alone streaming service and its strategies to drive viewers to the network at The New York Timess New Work Summit.

title: A Taunt From Dimon That Wells Fargo Would Be Reckless to Heed
description: It sounds as if Jamie Dimon has been brushing up on his Sun Tzu.

title: Jailed Afghan Women Are Often Subjected to Virginity Tests, Report Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Women and girls in Afghan jails are frequently subjected to forced virginity tests, advocates from Afghanistans human rights commission said on Tuesday, calling for an end to a discredited practice that is both invasive and degrading.

title: N.H.L. This Week: Top Rookies to Meet for First Time
description: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot  or not so hot  teams and players. (All times Eastern.)

title: Craig Windham, Top-of-the-Hour Voice of NPR, Dies at 66
description: Craig Windham, a veteran NPR reporter known for delivering bite-size reports for top-of-the-hour newscasts in a warm, familiar tone to millions of Americans, died on Sunday in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 66.

title: Switch to a $1 Coin
description: To the Editor:

title: College Presidents With Business Ties
Evangelicals and Donald Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Masahisa Fukases Hibi Photographs
description: The late photographer exhibited this series for one night in Tokyo in 1991, the last time the works have been shown, until now.

title: At the Armory Show, Little-Seen Works by an Acclaimed Photographer
description: To say that the photographer Masahisa Fukase has new work at the Armory Show this week wouldnt be entirely accurate: His series on display, Hibi, was created in the early 1990s. But soon after, the artist fell down the stairs of a bar in Tokyo, entering a coma that lasted until his death in 2012. As a result, his international reputation, which had flourished in the years before his accident, suddenly stalled; while he lay in a coma, his archive was held by a gallery in Japan, and it became near-impossible for European and American galleries and publishers to borrow original prints. Hibi was only exhibited by the artist for one evening in 1991 (and is still marked with pinholes from that show), and has never before been seen outside Tokyo. Twelve prints, which will be on view this week, debut exclusively here.

title: What to Do About the Rikers Island Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Flower Shopping with Susan Orlean
description: The authors new text, The Floral Ghost, laments the bygone heyday of New Yorks flower district.

title: Malian Jihadist Speaks at the Trial
description: Prosecutors at the International Criminal Court accused Ahmed al-Faqi al-Mahdi of war crimes for attacking the centuries-old world heritage site of Timbuktu.

title: A Spin Through the Flower District with Susan Orlean
description: Early one recent morning at the midtown New York flower wholesaler Dutch Flower Line, the author Susan Orlean paused to smell a fragrant bouquet of baby-blue hyacinth. With a light flurry of snow falling outside, the incongruity of her surroundings was not lost on her. New York, she noted, has a great talent for creating worlds inside worlds. Orlean is, of course, no stranger to uncovering the unusual. She traveled deep into Floridas swampy Fakahatchee Strand State Preserve with the orchid poacher John Laroche for her widely read 1998 book The Orchid Thief, which laid bare the little-known floral black market while also chronicling her own personal revelations along the way.

title: Scott Kelly, American Astronaut, Returns to Earth After 340 Days in Space
description: After 340 days in space, Scott Kelly is back on Earth.

title: CBS Hires Josh Elliott for Its Streaming Service
description: CBS announced on Tuesday that it had hired the former ABC and NBC anchor Josh Elliott to work for its streaming service.

title: World Chess Championship Returning to New York City
description: For the first time in more than two decades, and only the fourth time in the past century, the World Chess Championship will be held in New York City.

title: Erin Andrews Says Hotel Could Have Prevented Stalker From Filming Her
description: In the seven years since Erin Andrews learned that a man had surreptitiously taken video of her while she was naked in a hotel room, she has been forced to relive the memory daily, the Fox sportscaster told a Nashville court this week.

title: F.B.I. Error Locked San Bernardino Attackers iPhone
description: WASHINGTON  The head of the F.B.I. acknowledged on Tuesday that his agency lost a chance to capture data from the iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino attackers when it ordered that his password to the online storage service iCloud be reset shortly after the rampage.

title: State Department Fixes Unfair Visa Change
description: The latest blunder in the governments management of a special visa program for Afghan interpreters was fixed this week.

title: How Did You Manage a Breakup on Facebook?
description: Facebook is testing tools to make it easier for users to manage their interactions on the social network after a breakup.

title: Brazil Arrests Facebook Executive in WhatsApp Data Access Case
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazilian federal police arrested a Facebook executive on Tuesday after the company failed to turn over information from a WhatsApp messaging account that a judge had requested for a drug trafficking investigation.

title: Auto Sales Up in February, Helped by Cheap Gas and Easy Credit
description: Several automakers on Tuesday reported substantial increases in sales in the United States in February, as consumers continued to take advantage of cheap gas and easy credit to buy new vehicles.

title: Donald Drumpf Is Beating Rubio and Cruz for Second in Google Searches
description: Tuesday morning I wrote about how real-time Google search data can provide useful election forecasts. With half the day gone and voters in Super Tuesday states still at the polls, Google Trends reveals a striking observation about Donald Trumps dominance in the public mind.

title: Idris Elba to Star in Film of Stephen Kings Dark Tower
description: Idris Elba is stepping into a legendary gunslinger role  but its not James Bond. The actor has been cast alongside Matthew McConaughey in the long-awaited film adaptation of Stephen Kings The Dark Tower series. Mr. King confirmed the news on Twitter.

title: What the Polls Say About Super Tuesday and Beyond
description: An array of new polls suggests that Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton will dominate Super Tuesday contests. If the polls are correct, the size of those wins could determine whether other candidates are left with any reasonable chance of securing the nomination.

title: Aziz Ansari Returns to His Roots
description: The actor and comedian was raised in the American South on a diet of spicy curry and fried chicken. Hoping to make sense of his place in the world, he traveled to India, and let his stomach lead the way.

title: Travel Diary: T Goes on the Road With Aziz Ansari
description: Our senior features editor Nicholas Haramis accompanied the actor and comedian to India  and shares his personal snapshots from the trip here.

title: Aziz Ansari Goes to India
description: The actor and comedian was raised in the American South on a diet of spicy curry and fried chicken. Hoping to make sense of his place in the world, he returned to his roots, and let his stomach lead the way.

title: Swiping a Priceless Antiquity ... With a Scanner and a 3-D Printer
description: Editors Note: March 10, 2016

title: Seattle Underbelly Exposed as Homeless Camp Violence Flares
description: SEATTLE  So dangerous is this citys biggest homeless camp, called the Jungle  three ragged miles stitched along the underbelly of Interstate 5  that if a fire broke out there today, firefighters would not be allowed in without an armed police escort. State lawmakers are considering closing the camp by erecting a razor-wire fence around it, at a cost of $1 million.

title: Anthony Vaccarello: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Vaccarello presents his collection for fall 2016.

title: Olympics Is Opening Its Rings to Professional Boxers
description: The Olympics, once a bastion of the amateur ideal, have in recent years welcomed millionaire professionals like Roger Federer and LeBron James, and this summer they will host top golfers like Rory McIlroy.

title: Aroldis Chapmans Stance Changed From Defiance to Acceptance
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Aroldis Chapman stood at his locker in the Yankees spring training clubhouse last week, he was resolute in defending himself. He knew that Major League Baseball was investigating his actions in an October episode in which, according to a police report, he placed his hands around his girlfriends neck during an argument and fired a gun eight times. He knew he was in great danger of being suspended.

title: Name Your Supreme Court Pick, President Obama
description: More than two weeks after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, President Obama has not named a nominee for the vacant seat on the Supreme Court. Instead, he appears to be succumbing once again to his persistent belief that congressional Republicans can be reasoned with if only he tries hard enough.

title: Does a Carbon Tax Work? Ask British Columbia
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Ted Cruz says climate change is not happening. Donald Trump says he doesnt believe in it. Marco Rubio, whose hometown, Miami, is projected to be largely underwater within the not too distant future as ice caps shrink and the sea level rises, argues that government efforts to combat it will destroy our economy.

title: Salesforces Womens Surge
description: Marc Benioff, chairman and chief executive of Salesforce, discussed at The New York Timess New Work Summit how his company has tried to provide more and better opportunities for women.

title: Roadside Bomb in Pakistan Kills 2 Employees of U.S. Consulate
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two Pakistani employees of the United States Consulate in Peshawar were killed Tuesday by a roadside bomb in northwestern Pakistan, officials said.

title: Lawmakers Urge Greater Care With Sales of Distressed Mortgages
description: Dozens of lawmakers sent a letter on Tuesday to housing regulators urging them to disqualify aggressive investors from the sales of distressed mortgages by the Federal Housing Administration, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and asking them to provide more details about loan sales and their outcomes.

title: Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell Say No to Klan (but Maybe to Donald Trump)
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Paul D. Ryan on Tuesday forcefully denounced Donald J. Trumps refusal to distance himself from the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke. But Mr. Ryan did not shift from his position that he would support Mr. Trump if he became the Republican Partys presidential nominee, a perplexing contradiction that reflects the growing anxiety on Capitol Hill over the billionaire businessmans ascent.

title: Lucky Blue Smith Has to Finish His Homework
description: He is 17 years old, has 2.1 million Instagram followers and is surely the most hyped male model on the planet. But Lucky Blue Smith found time to take a spot in the front row of the Anthony Vaccarello show on Tuesday, the first day of Paris Fashion Week.

title: New York Attorney Generals Suit Against Trump University May Proceed, Court Rules
description: A New York appeals court decided on Tuesday that a lawsuit brought by the state attorney general claiming that Donald J. Trumps defunct for-profit school defrauded consumers can go forward.

title: Italy Moves to Toughen Penalties for Olive Oil Fraud
description: ROME  Italian lawmakers voted on Tuesday to stiffen a legislative decree that Italian olive oil producers and other critics charged would decriminalize olive oil counterfeiting.

title: Review: A Big Cool Breeze of Rick Bass Stories
description: If you came of age as a magazine reader in the late 1980s and early 90s, you became accustomed to finding Rick Basss short stories in the better localities: The Atlantic, Esquire, The New Yorker, GQ, The Paris Review.

title: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
description: The United States and More  Photos of the Day

title: Dr. Holbrook Kohrt, Hemophiliac Who Made Condition a Crusade, Dies at 38
description: Dr. Holbrook Kohrt, a hemophiliac who transformed his own chronic condition into a personal and public crusade for medical cures, died last Wednesday in Miami. He was 38.

title: March 1, 2016  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, France, Greece and Cuba.

title: Prosecutors Lay Out Case Against Suspect in Destruction of Mali Shrines
description: PARIS  International prosecutors on Tuesday laid out charges in their first case involving Islamic extremism, accusing a jihadist from Mali of destroying historic Muslim shrines in Timbuktu that were protected as a World Heritage Site.

title: Review: A Trio of Micro-Operas in the East Village
description: The past and future of experimental vocalism came together on Saturday, when Joan La Barbara and Gelsey Bell shared the stage at the Wild Project in the East Village for an enthralling trio of John Kings 20-minute micro-operas.

title: Review: A Family Full of Secrets in The Real ONeals
description: The Real ONeals wants desperately to be the brash new sitcom that talks forthrightly about subjects that had been taboo. And a decade or two ago it might have been. Now, though, its just the guest who arrives late to the party, blundering in loudly and clumsily.

title: Review: But I Cd Only Whisper, a Tale of a Violent Veteran
description: The term post-traumatic stress disorder inevitably comes up in diagnoses of the strange and tragic case of Beau Willie Brown. Hes a Vietnam War veteran and the charismatic force of destruction at the center of But I Cd Only Whisper, Kristiana Rae Colns feverishly poetic portrait of the life and times of a violent man, which is receiving its American premiere at the Flea Theater.

title: An Application and a Syllabus for Aspiring Jihadis
description: Al Qaeda was nothing if not bureaucratic. Among the documents found by Navy SEALs in Bin Laden's compound in May 2011 was a syllabus for a course to teach recruits about jihad, and an application for those who wished to join the terror network.

title: Osama Bin Laden's Will
description: A copy of a will that was apparently handwritten by Osama bin Laden in the 1990s was among thousands of documents seized by Navy SEALs who raided his compound in May 2011. The will is presented in its original Arabic with an English translation.

title: Bin Laden Asks Wife About Tracking Device in Tooth
description: In a letter to his wife written in January 2011, Osama bin Laden asked her for details of a filling that she had put in by an Iranian dentist, and that he feared could contain a tracking device. The letter was seized by Navy SEALs during their raid in 2011 and declassified on Tuesday.

title: Review: In Hap and Leonard Best Friends Get a Lucrative Job Offer
description: SundanceTVs new six-part drama Hap and Leonard is based on the books of Joe R. Lansdale, a Texas-based novelist (and martial-arts instructor). If youre not familiar with Mr. Lansdales work, youll still get your bearings quickly. The setting may be East Texas but were essentially in Elmore Leonard country, where sordid crime, snappy dialogue and regional atmosphere meet.

title: Review: In Dead Dog Park, a Police Chase, a Fall From a Window and Countering Theories
description: Its a good time to put on a play like Dead Dog Park, and that makes you wish that Dead Dog Park were a stronger play. For sure, several interesting moments emerge here. To get to them, however, requires patience, even for a show that runs just over an hour.

title: At Vaccarello, Natural Looks  and a Devilish Edge
description: Weve been working the past few seasons to create little details that make a girl whos very unique and very Vaccarello, said the makeup artist Tom Pecheux, backstage at Anthony Vaccarellos fall/winter 2016 show earlier today. To wit, the designers runway featured a parade of natural, effortless-looking beauties  and three devilish angels (or angelic devils  Pecheux couldnt decide).

title: Bill Cosbys Sexual Assault Case Is Halted Pending Appeals Courts Review
description: The criminal sexual assault case against the entertainer Bill Cosby was suspended on Tuesday by a Pennsylvania appeals court.

title: Vienna Philharmonic, Led by Valery Gergiev, Offers Old and New at Carnegie Hall
description: The Vienna Philharmonic offered unusually varied fare over the weekend in its annual visit to Carnegie Hall, heavy in a longtime specialty  the music of Wagner  but also presenting a major new work by Olga Neuwirth. And as so often, the orchestras social and political history lurked in the background, thanks to the recent publication of an essay on its website updating the history of its interrelationships with Nazi authorities and activities after Hitlers annexation of Austria in 1938.

title: How Xerox Is Building on Its Copier Legacy
description: Ursula Burns, the chief executive of Xerox, talked at The New York Times's New Media Summit about why still being considered synonymous with photocopiers can be an asset for its new initiatives, especially as the company prepares to split.

title: Review: In Songs My Brothers Taught Me, Reservation Dreams and Their Limits
description: Songs My Brothers Taught Me, a melancholic portrait of Lakota Indian life on the Pine Ridge Reservation in the South Dakota Badlands, suggests a Native American answer to The Last Picture Show. As in the dying Texas town where that movie is set, a demoralizing stasis prevails, along with a lingering pride in tribal rituals that preserve a sense of continuity. When the residents don traditional headdresses and dance around a bonfire, there is joy in the air.

title: Tenure Voting Could Shift the Balance of Corporate Power
description: A great divide exists in the voting power of shareholders in the United States.

title: Android, Kindle, and Start-Up Subcultures
description: Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn, and Joichi Ito, director of the MIT Media Lab, discussed at The Timess New Media Summit the value of separating new ideas inside big companies so they don't get suffocated by the main business.

title: Inside the Met Breuer
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art hosted a preview to show off its new location for Modern and contemporary art in the former home of the Whitney.

title: A Look at the Met Breuer Before the Doors Open
description: When the world was given a pre-opening peek in 1966 at the building designed by Marcel Breuer on East 75th Street and Madison Avenue, the new home of the Whitney Museum of American Art, the ceremony was nearly canceled because of a bomb threat, one that would have sent luminaries like Jacqueline Kennedy and Mayor John V. Lindsay into the streets.

title: Google Searches Point to a Strong Showing for Donald Trump
description: It looks as if Donald Trump is going to have a big night, judging from what could be a newly useful measure, Google searches.

title: Super Tuesday: Big Night for Trump and Clinton as Rivals Hold On
description: (Find highlights and analysis here.)

title: At Memorial, Scalia Remembered as Happy Combatant
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Clarence Thomas paid tribute on Tuesday to Brother Nino at a memorial service for Justice Antonin Scalia at the Mayflower Hotel attended by all eight remaining members of the Supreme Court.

description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Woman Charged With Tricking Men Into Giving Her Cash
description: She would approach older men in Upper Manhattan restaurants or supermarkets, pretending she knew them, prosecutors said. She would get their contact information and from there, forge a relationship and gain their trust. That is when she asked for money.

title: Nabil Maleh, Giant of Syrian Cinema, Dies at 79
description: Nabil Maleh, who used social realism to challenge authority and became, in many critics estimation, the father of Syrian cinema, died on Feb. 24 in Dubai. He was 79.

title: Argentinas Hedge Fund Deal Frustrates Small Bondholders
description: Argentinas offer to pay billions to settle a dispute with a group of hedge fund investors led by the billionaire Paul E. Singer may have been a victory for both the South American nation and the hedge funds, but it has left many small bondholders out in the cold.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: How North Korea Poses a Threat
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved a resolution on Wednesday that toughens sanctions on North Korea in response to its latest nuclear weapons testing and the launching of a ballistic missile.

title: A Conversation With Paul L. Whalen
description: Mr. Whalen, 60, is a design partner of Robert A. M. Stern Architects. He has been the lead designer on buildings like 15 Central Park West, where an apartment once held the record for New York Citys most expensive residence, at $88 million, and 220 Central Park South, where a triplex is now under contract for $200 million.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: $20/square foot

title: South Dakota Governor Vetoes Restriction on Transgender Bathroom Access
description: The Republican governor of South Dakota on Tuesday vetoed a bill that would have restricted bathroom access for transgender students and made the state the first to adopt such a measure.

title: Rays to Play Cuban National Team in Havana
description: The Tampa Bay Rays will play an exhibition game against the Cuban national team March 22 in Havana, Major League Baseball and the players union announced Tuesday. President Obama is expected to attend the game at Estadio Latinoamericano, according to an official involved in its planning, which coincides with Mr. Obamas visit to the island this month.

title: Mark Pincus, Founder of Zynga, Is Replaced as C.E.O. Again
description: Less than a year ago, Zynga, the online games maker behind Words With Friends and other titles, brought back its founder, Mark Pincus, to run the struggling company.

title: Virginia Exit Polls

title: 92 New York City High Schools to Give No-Fee SAT on Wednesday
description: On Wednesday, juniors at 92 New York City high schools will pick up their pencils, open their test booklets and take the SAT, with no fee and during regular school hours. It is the first step in a plan to give the test next year in all 438 city high schools, which the de Blasio administration hopes will help make college more accessible for thousands of students.

title: Jets Assign Franchise Tag to Muhammad Wilkerson and Raise Season-Ticket Prices
description: The Jets officially designated the star defensive lineman Muhammad Wilkerson as their franchise player Tuesday, all but ensuring that he will remain with the team for one more season.

description: Live estimates of the number of delegates each Republican candidate will pick up on Super Tuesday.

title: As Air Worsens, New Delhi Turns to Masks. The Flashier the Better.
description: NEW DELHI  It isnt just sweaters the kindergartners are wearing as they pour out of their classrooms onto the lawns of the American Embassy School in Indias capital city.

title: Sanders Speaks After Winning Vermont
description: Bernie Sanders addressed a crowd in Vermont after he won the Democratic presidential primary there on Super Tuesday.

title: Minority Voters Push Hillary Clinton to Victories
description: Hillary Clinton took full command of the Democratic presidential race on Tuesday as she rolled to major victories over Bernie Sanders in Texas, Virginia and across the South and proved for the first time that she could build a national coalition of racially diverse voters that would be crucial in the November election.

title: Politics Edge Onto the Greens at a Course Owned by Donald Trump
description: DORAL, Fla.  At 8:30 Tuesday morning, Raymond Corica stood behind the practice green at Dorals Blue Monster holding a Sharpie pen and a photograph that he hoped to get signed. Autograph seekers converge on every PGA Tour stop bearing glossy prints for the players to sign, but this was different. The picture in Coricas hand, taken at last years World Golf Championships event here, showed Corica standing next to Donald J. Trump, the Trump National Doral resort owner and unofficial tournament host.

title: U.S. Captures ISIS Operative, Ushering in Tricky Phase
description: WASHINGTON  An elite American Special Operations force has captured a significant Islamic State operative in Iraq and is expected to apprehend and interrogate a number of others in coming months, ushering in a new and potentially fraught phase in the fight against the extremist Sunni militant group.

title: The Party of Trump, and the Path Forward for Democrats
description: The strength of Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton in the Super Tuesday primary contests, evident before the first votes were cast, brings the 2016 presidential race to a point of reckoning. Not enough delegates were at stake to give either candidate a mathematical lock on a nomination, but voters can see the shape of the choice facing them in the general election.

title: Who Will Win Super Tuesday? Live Estimates of Tonights Final Democratic Results
description: Live estimates of the number of delegates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders will pick up on Super Tuesday.

title: Court Hears Suit Against U.N. on Haiti Cholera Outbreak
description: A legal battle by the Haitian victims of a cholera epidemic against the United Nations reached its highest level in an American court on Tuesday, as lawyers for the plaintiffs were permitted to argue before a federal appeals panel why they believe the United Nations is not entitled to immunity.

title: Dia Art Foundation Adds Two Board Members
description: The Dia Art Foundation, which has been raising money and working for years toward re-establishing a strong presence in downtown Manhattan, where it was born in 1974, announced Tuesday that it had named two new high-profile members to its board.

title: Document Claims Drug Makers Deceived a Top Medical Journal
description: It is a startling accusation, buried in a footnote in a legal briefing filed recently in federal court: Did two major pharmaceutical companies, in an effort to protect their blockbuster drug, mislead editors at one of the worlds most prestigious medical journals?

title: Bitter Contract Dispute Extends to Who Owns Yosemite Names
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  Marilyn and Jack Whitcher have been regular visitors to the glacier-carved valley of Yosemite National Park since they were dating more than five decades ago. This trip was different.

title: Mayor de Blasio, With Wary Eye on World Economy, Asks Agencies to Cut Costs
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has asked New York City commissioners to look for ways to cut costs in a gesture of fiscal moderation prompted by worries over the rocky world economy, drawing cautious praise from budget watchdogs.

title: Phil Jackson: A Zen Master, but Not When It Comes to Twitter
description: With all the attention Phil Jackson has received since Sunday for his comment about Stephen Curry on Twitter, it is worth recalling how he first announced his participation in the world of social media.

title: Thousands of New York City Students Deprived of Special-Education Services, Report Says
description: As many as 40 percent of students in New York City recommended for special-education services may not be getting them, the Education Department said in a report released on Monday.

title: Hillary Clintons Moment
description: You can look at Hillary Clintons path to this juncture and marvel at how difficult she has often made things for herself, creating messes where there didnt need to be any, frittering away advantages, misunderstanding the mood of voters, underestimating the mettle of opponents, and failing to cement an image  and a message  that seemed authentic and right.

title: White House Officials Soften Approach at RSA Conference
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch joined a parade of Obama administration officials to techs home turf on Tuesday. Their message: National security depends on the industrys cooperation.

title: Thousands Honor Virginia Officer Killed on Her First Day on the Job

title: Stock Exchange Prices Grow So Convoluted Even Traders Are Confused, Study Finds
description: Computer-driven American stock markets have become so complex that at any moment in time more than 800 different pricing possibilities are being offered to trading firms across 12 official exchanges, according to new research attempting to explain the tangled system.

title: Pennsylvania Diocese Leaders Knew of Sex Abuse for Decades, Grand Jury Says
description: Over four decades, at least 50 priests and other church employees molested hundreds of children in a small Roman Catholic diocese in central Pennsylvania, and in many cases their superiors knew of the abuses but did not remove the priests or notify law enforcement, according to a grand jury report released on Tuesday.

Trump won sweeping victories across the South and in New England on Tuesday, a show of strength in the Republican primary campaign that underscored the breadth of his appeal and helped him begin to amass a wide delegate advantage despite growing resistance to his candidacy among party leaders.

title: Sanders Campaign Will Travel On, but Path to Victory Is All but Blocked

The miracle of this cookie is that, besides being delicious and the official dessert of the New York Times crossword, there are still things to discover about it.

description: The stone-face house at No. 745 had become somewhat of a mystery to the residents of Barbey Street in East New York, Brooklyn. For decades, a woman named Gloria Knight had lived there with her husband.

title: Summonses, Not Arrests, for Small Crimes in Manhattan
description: Police officers in Manhattan will no longer arrest most people who commit minor offenses like urinating in public and riding between subway cars under a policy shift announced on Tuesday that officials hope will help to reduce a backlog of cases pending in Criminal Court.

The 47th annual induction ceremony will take place at the Marriott Marquis in New York on June 9.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Day 2
description: A wet, pasty grayness hung over Paris on Tuesday, dampening (in all senses of the word) the first day of Paris Fashion Week. It was insult added to injury that as the gathered tribes  those weary fashion soldiers who have trouped from New York to London to Milan to Paris  checked their bags at Linate and Malpensa airports in Italy, the sun was shining brightly and the temperatures climbed to nearly 60 degrees.

title: Young Africans, Wrapped in Tradition
description: The young woman sat proudly, firmly placing her hand below her chin to profile her face. Colorful silk fabric was neatly wrapped around her chest, while the studio light and golden backdrop bathed her gently oiled skin. Small circular tribal markings were tattooed on her upper body. Her neck and wrists were adorned with layers of beaded jewelry.

title: Beware: Exploding Politics
description: When the U.S. military trains fighter pilots, it uses a concept called the OODA loop. It stands for observe, orient, decide, act. The idea is that if your ability to observe, orient, decide and act in a dogfight at 30,000 feet is faster than the other pilots, youll shoot his plane out of the sky. If the other pilots OODA loop is faster, hell shoot you out of the sky. For a while now, its been obvious that our national OODA loop is broken  and it couldnt be happening at a worse time.

title: The iPhone Stays Locked, for Now
description: The Justice Department has argued that Apple has a legal responsibility to help the government unlock iPhones that may contain evidence needed in criminal investigations. A federal judge in Brooklyn argues, persuasively, that the company is not obligated to do so.

title: Can the Sanders Movement Go Local?
description: FROM the start, Bernie Sanders has insisted that his bid for president is more than just a bid for president. This campaign is not about electing Bernie Sanders for president, the campaign tweeted in August. It is about creating a grass-roots political movement in this country.

title: Making Policing Safer for Everyone
description: POLICE sergeants routinely tell their officers that their most important job is to make it home safely. And it is no wonder why they dispense this advice. With an estimated 350 million firearms in the United States, officers daily face the threat of gun violence, making this country far more dangerous for the police than countries with tight controls on guns.

title: Statistics From China Say Coal Consumption Continues to Drop
description: BEIJING  China has released new statistics indicating that it used less coal last year than in 2014, lending support to the view that the country, the worlds largest emitter of carbon dioxide, may have reached a peak in coal consumption.

description: In a small Brooklyn apartment, Jacob Winterhalt, a former Air Force airman, looked on as his 3-year-old daughter, Raya, and her best friend, Doris, chased each other. The girls wore sneakers. Doriss were equipped with red lights that flashed with the urgency of a distress beacon.

title: Major League Baseball Wants to Let Cuban Players Sign Directly With Teams
description: Major League Baseball has submitted a proposal to the Treasury Department that outlines a new pathway for baseball players from Cuba to sign directly with big league teams in the United States. If approved, it could represent a sea change in relations between the two countries and drastically reshape how Cuban players find their way to the major leagues.

description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court appeared splintered on Wednesday during arguments in a major abortion case that could affect the lives of millions of American women.
