title: Locked Away for 24 Years, an Exonerated Man Still Feels Imprisoned
description: Han Tak Lee, 81, spends much of his time alone in a small room in Queens. It is a ground-floor studio apartment with a kitchenette and a bathroom, right beside train tracks used by the Long Island Rail Road. Commuter trains roar by every so often, though the double-glazing of his windows reduces the noise to a gentle whoosh.

title: Draghis Plan Lifts Markets, but Clouds Loom on the Horizon
description: Mario Draghi has rediscovered his mojo.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Krisha
description: Trey Edward Shults narrates a sequence from his drama Krisha.

title: How an Amateur Meteorite Hunter Tracked Down a Fireball
description: When a fireball whizzed over Florida on Jan. 24, more than a hundred witnesses reported spotting the flare on the American Meteor Societys website. Within a week, Mike Hankey, an amateur meteorite hunter based nearly a thousand miles away near Baltimore, was holding a muddy chunk of the space rock he found near a swamp.

title: Parole for Killer of Chris Hani, Apartheid Opponent, Elicits an Outcry
description: A South African judge granted parole on Thursday to the killer of Chris Hani, a leading anti-apartheid activist who was assassinated in 1993. The decision to release the killer, Janusz Walus, provoked immediate criticism and revived painful memories of a murder aimed at derailing the countrys transition to black-majority rule.

title: Trey Edward Shults Narrates a Scene From Krisha
description: With Krisha, the writer and director Trey Edward Shults made a family drama using his actual family.

title: Simon & Schuster to Publish Writings of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
description: My Own Words, a collection of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburgs writings, will be published by Simon & Schuster in January. The book will include her writing and speeches on a variety of subjects, like her Jewish identity, gender equality, interpreting the Constitution, and the way lawyers and the law are depicted in opera. It will have an introduction by Justice Ginsburg, who was appointed to the Supreme Court in 1993.

title: With Krisha, a Director Finds a Cast He Can Relate To
description: We felt like a family is a sentiment often voiced by actors about smooth productions. But when the filmmaker Trey Edward Shults says the same about Krisha, his debut feature film, hes just stating facts. His mother, aunts and even grandmother all star in the film  as does he.

title: The Value of Autopsies for Doctors and D.A.s
description: To the Editor:

title: In Israel, an Arab Chooses Baskets Over Goals
description: NAZARETH, Israel  Long before he was a professional basketball player in Israels most prestigious league, Karam Mashour honed his game on one of the only courts in this city: the tiny alleyway between his parents house and his grandmothers. The narrow sliver of concrete and its portable hoop came with specific challenges  duck low if you want to dribble to the right but avoid a collision with the electrical box jutting out from the window, for example  yet Mashour never dwelled on the setting.

title: An Invitation to Voters: Share Your Hopes and Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: Warner Bros. Announces Incubator for Underrepresented Talent
description: LOS ANGELES  Having had its feet held to the fire during the recent Oscar season over a lack of diversity, Hollywood is scrambling to cast more actors of color, support films that tell stories from nonwhite perspectives and hire directors who are not white men. The latest effort came on Thursday, with Warner Bros. saying it would start an incubator to provide access and voice to new and underrepresented talent.

title: What Does Trump Mean for the G.O.P.?
description: Republican voters we interviewed over the past six months expressed elation, frustration, happiness and fear over the effect one man, Donald J. Trump, is having on a political party facing upheaval in 2016.

title: 36 Hours in Zurich
description: To a yearlong celebration of the centenary of Dada, you can add first-rate restaurants, Art Deco bars and a lake cruise with views of the Alps.

title: Black Protester Is Sucker-Punched by White Donald Trump Supporter at Rally
description: Join us for live updates of the Republican debate.

title: Biden, on Jordan Visit, Meets With King Abdullah II
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. held talks in Jordan on Wednesday with King Abdullah II on a variety of regional topics, including the fight against the Islamic State.

title: The Assets of the Ultrarich Come Closer to Earth
description: Last year, a Manhattan penthouse sold for $100 million and another went into contract for $200 million. Christies auctioned Picassos Women of Algiers for $179 million, and Sothebys sold the 12-carat Blue Moon of Josephine diamond for $48.4 million. A vintage Jaguar sold for $13.2 million.

title: Snap Sketch: The Faces of Paris Fashion Week
description: The illustrator Damien Florbert Cuypers draws the models, designers, buyers and bloggers at the fall/winter 2016 collections.

title: Fundamentals, Polls, and the Primary
description: The huge polling miss in Michigan was a cautionary tale: for all its excellence, FiveThirtyEight is only as good as the polls, which at least this time were way, way off. Its too soon to dismiss them, but not too soon to explore other approaches, which is what Alan Abramowitz has just done. Using data for the Dem contests so far, he estimates a simple relationship based on just two factors  nonwhite share of the population, and north versus south  that accounts for the results quite well  and Michigan is not an outlier.

title: North Carolina Exemplifies National Battles Over Voting Laws
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The purest distillation of the nations wars over voting rules and legislative gerrymandering is playing out in North Carolina.

title: The Eight Best Bags of Paris Fashion Week
description: A mini saddlebag got dressed up with studs and a large jeweled brooch for a bit of Western glam.

title: Energy Transfers Deal Is a Nightmare With No Escape
description: Energy Transfer Equitys acquisition of a rival pipeline company, Williams Companies, has turned into a nightmare as troubles in the energy industry worsen.

title: Ts 50 Best Photos of Fashion Month
description: Highlights from the fall/winter 2016 shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris  on and off the runway.

title: The Seven Biggest Beauty Trends From Fashion Week
description: Highlights from the fall/winter 2016 runways.

title: My Job: Watch Downton Abbey. Poor Me.
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion pieces come together at The New York Times. In this piece, writer Louis Bayard describes what it was like to write The Timess Downton Abbey recaps.

title: Review: Christopher Plummer Searches for a Nazi in Remember
description: Christopher Plummer puts on a master class in acting, and his director, Atom Egoyan, delivers one in audience manipulation in Remember, a psychological thriller featuring that most blood-boiling of plot devices: a Nazi who escaped justice.

title: Great Gray Owl Female Contact Call
description: Biologists in Yosemite play back recorded owl vocalizations like this one to encourage responses that can determine presence and provide hints about breeding status. This recording is of a common whoop call, often heard when a female owl contacts a male.

title: Great Gray Owl Begging Fledgling Call
description: This call, typical of young owls requesting food, is useful as evidence for biologists attempting to home in on the location of nests. As a recording, it can also be used to elicit responses from other owls.

title: Living With Cancer: Being Erased
description: While I recover from a fractured pelvis, I have time to remember the day after a less ruinous fall two years ago. No bones broken then, but I quickly developed a shiner and then slowly an insight into the color of cancer.

title: Review: Rise of the Legend, a Kung Fu Period Film
description: The blending of vast sets and digital effects is not quite seamless in Chow Hin Yeungs kung fu period extravaganza Rise of the Legend, but its close. Revisiting the story of Wong Fei Hung, a martial arts master whose life has passed into Chinese folklore, Legend takes place in 19th-century Guangzhou, where two crime factions vie for control of the docks. This movies Guangzhou is a marvel: sprawling, detailed, abounding in narrow alleys and vivid street scenes.

title: In Trudeau and Obama, the Internet Sees a Budding Bromance
description: It was, as President Obama put it in the most American of jokes, aboot time, eh?

title: Review: Hyena Road Follows a Sniper Team in Afghanistan
description: Afghanistan has been a combat zone for so long that its become a film genre unto itself, with documentaries like Restrepo, features like Lone Survivor, even comedies like Whiskey Tango Foxtrot. Now a Canadian movie, Hyena Road, adds another perspective.

title: A Trip Through Amazons First Physical Store
description: This week, Amazon revealed the location of its second brick-and-mortar bookstore, which will open in a few months in Southern California, at a mall near the University of California, San Diego. The online retailer seems to have big ambitions for its physical stores.

title: Review: 10 Cloverfield Lane Houses a Survivalist, His Captive and Jolts
description: 10 Cloverfield Lane demands to be seen before reading a single review. So I plan to divulge even less than its makers, whose hype-by-omission campaign  which included a late title change to summon fans of J. J. Abramss hurtling thriller Cloverfield (2008)  seems unnecessarily manipulative.

title: Ad Watch: Offering Salvation for Americans Fleeing Politics
description: During presidential election years, Americans of varying political persuasions often contemplate moving to Canada. Google queries for Canada spike. Conversations between friends turn to preferred Canadian destinations.

title: IndyCar Chief Looks to Build Interest Beyond the 100th Indianapolis 500
description: Mark Miles often has lunch at a restaurant not far from his office at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He says he is often stopped by race fans who tell him what the Indianapolis 500 means to them. The race, for many, is still a deeply cherished tradition.

title: Review: The Brothers Grimsby: From Sacha, With Love
description: A Freudian might be able to make something of Sacha Baron Cohens emphasis on bodily orifices and protrusions in The Brothers Grimsby. I prefer a more obvious explanation: At some point during the making of this 1-hour-18-minute burlesque, Mr. Cohen became bored. Given the production budget, the pitch was obviously good enough for someone to write a check and hire an action director, Louis Leterrier, who could give the material the requisite spit-shine: After years of separation, two drastically different brothers  a sleek superspy and a bumbling fool  reunite and, in between guffaws, heal old wounds, zip around the world and fight a global crime syndicate.

title: 3 Survivor Contestants Collapse in Cambodian Heat, and One Is Evacuated
description: For the better part of the 16 years it has been on the air, Survivor hasnt really been about actually surviving.

title: In Rivettes Out 1: Noli Me Tangere, Paris Is a Stage
description: Jacques Rivette, who died in January  at 87, was in some ways the most classical of French New Wave directors (adapting Denis Diderot and Balzac, celebrating Joan of Arc), and in others the most experimental. His more radical movies were extended meta-dramas that conflated narrative with conspiracy, and actors were typically cast in the role of actors.

title: Review: In About Scout, a Young Woman Searches for Her Sister
description: About Scout is another entry in the charming road movie genre, one that banks a little too heavily on charm and not enough on story. The two young leads pair engagingly, though, and the screenwriter and director, Laurie Weltz, surrounds them with name actors in small roles, a sweet reversal of the usual casting structure.

title: 8 Compelling Mini-Documentaries to Teach Close Reading and Critical Thinking Skills
description: From the days when instructional films like these were shown via projector, students have enjoyed watching movies in class. Teachers have too. But its often hard to justify watching a two-hour film when theres so much else that has to be done.

title: Review: Boom Bust Boom, a Pythonesque Look at Financial Crashes
description: This film is about the Achilles heel of capitalism, Terry Jones says at the opening of Boom Bust Boom. How human nature drives the economy to crisis after crisis, time and time again.

title: Review: In Julie Delpys Lolo, a Teenager Tries to Sabotage His Mothers Romance
description: With Lolo, Julie Delpy (2 Days in New York) makes a much simpler addition to her prickly, idiosyncratic comedies, which have doubled as a frank running commentary on life (as with her roles in Richard Linklaters films). In Ms. Delpys broadest effort yet  which she directs, and wrote with Eugnie Grandval  she plays a Paris fashionista who dotes on a snooty son and finds their clingy bond getting in the way of a rejuvenating romance.

title: Apple and U.S. Bitterly Turn Up Volume in iPhone Privacy Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration argued on Thursday that no single corporation  even one as successful as Apple  should be allowed to flout the rule of law by refusing to help the F.B.I. unlock the iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino, Calif., attackers.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, March 12 Through 27
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Reporter Says Donald Trumps Campaign Manager Yanked Her Arm
description: Donald J. Trump often excoriates the news media, calling reporters dishonest or disgusting.

title: Top 10 Moments From Paris Fashion Week
description: Balenciagas new chapter, Iris Apfels whirlwind week and more highlights from the fall/winter 2016 shows.

title: Review: Mabel Madness, a Singers 20th-Century Journey
description: In 1900, in a riverside town near Birmingham, England, a 14-year-old white girl who worked in vaudeville had a baby fathered by a fellow vaudevillian, a black American. And so the story behind Mabel Madness, Trezana Beverleys consistently beguiling solo show at Urban Stages, began.

title: Mexican Crime Photographs / from the archive of Stefan Ruiz
description: The photographer Stefan Ruizs new book collects mug shots and crime-scene photos  made all the more striking for their lack of context.

title: Haunting Found Images From Mexico Citys Police Archives
description: While visiting La Lagunilla, a public market in Mexico City, in 2010, the photographer Stefan Ruiz came upon a collection of the citys police archives of crime photographs. Intrigued, he spent the next six months buying hundreds of them, which he has now collected into a new book, Mexican Crime Photographs / from the archive of Stefan Ruiz. Fascinated by the pasts of these unknown men and women, Ruiz continued his search and uncovered more photographs  both images of crimes taking place, such as a dramatic armed bank robbery, and many mug shots of recently arrested suspects. The impact of these photos is all the more powerful for their lack of context: As viewers, we can only imagine their stories, and reckon with realities that might sharply differ from our stereotypical understanding of Mexicos tragically crime-ridden history.

title: For China Banks, Swapping Stock for Debt Is a Stopgap With Pitfalls
description: HONG KONG  A new approach to managing Chinas corporate debt burden may offer temporary relief for banks but spell further difficulties for the countrys economy: having deeply troubled companies use stock to pay overdue loans.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Art in review, from Times critics.

title: California Water District Fined by S.E.C. Over Enron Accounting
description: When the overseers of the nations largest and most powerful agricultural water district approved a bookkeeping change at their July 2010 board meeting, the districts general manager called it a little Enron accounting.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, March 12 Through 27
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Mystery Deepens Over Death of Former Putin Ally Mikhail Lesin
description: WASHINGTON  Mikhail Y. Lesin once occupied the upper stratosphere of Vladimir V. Putins Russia, an advertising executive turned cabinet minister who helped carry out the state takeover of the countrys independent media and later created the Kremlins global English-language television network.

title: Sketches From a P.O.W. Camp That Held African-Americans and Others
description: During World War II, the Nazis imprisoned African-American athletes and jazz musicians and European Jews with passports from the United States and Latin America at Tittmoning Castle in Bavaria. The black detainees had been working overseas, partly to escape racism at home, and some had European wives and children who were also taken to interment centers.

title: Bernie Sanders Draws Thousands at Rallies Across Florida
description: Join us for live updates of the Republican debate.

title: Review: Rene Fleming, a Voice With Wardrobe Changes
description: Rene Flemings song recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, with the pianist Olga Kern, promised to be a big event, in ways both good and possibly less good. Ms. Fleming recently made known that she intends to phase out her operatic career, but her voice is still in excellent shape, and this program could indicate that she will invest more heavily in the song repertory.

title: How a Rembrandt Masterpiece Evolved
description: It isnt just that Rembrandts Judas Returning the Thirty Pieces of Silver is recognized as the artists first masterpiece. Or that it hasnt been seen in the United States before. What makes the Morgan Library & Museums coming exhibition noteworthy is that it will include three preparatory drawings of the painting, making it one of Rembrandts only works for which such sketches survive.

title: The Obama-Trudeau Climate Pledge Contains Overdue Steps to Fix Natural Gas Leaks
description: Todays Joint Statement on Climate, Energy, and Arctic Leadershipby President Obama and Canadas new prime minister, Justin Trudeau, contained lots of welcome environmental commitments, particularly on curbing emissions of methane leaking from existing oil and gas infrastructure. They pledged to cutsuch emissions 40 to 45 percent below 2012 levels by 2025 from the oil and gas sector.

title: Review: The Hospital: 3 Nurses, No Patients, Dark Ritual
description: The three nurses in the Norwegian Jo Stromgren Kompanis The Hospital look bored to death. Now and then, they hear a helicopter fly over their outpost but no one lands. And so the nurses take turns disappearing behind one of the sets dirty walls. Theres a whack and a howl and then a nurse returns bloodied: Finally, a patient!

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, March 12 Through 27
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Creative Control, a Satire of Gadget-Driven Reality
description: Concocted with heaps of style but only a smattering of substance, Benjamin Dickinsons sophomore feature, Creative Control, is as brittle and unwelcoming as its characters surroundings. Those would be Brooklyn, some time in the near future when everyone enjoys panoramic city views from habitats bristling with glass and chrome. Tactile surfaces, like emotional satisfaction, are in short supply.

title: One Model, 40 Beauty Looks
description: From a fresh face at Jason Wu to slicked-back tresses at Miu Miu, a months worth of Frederikke Sofies hair and makeup, in pictures.

title: Review: Marguerite, a Screeching Diva Clinging to Her Operatic Dream
description: The self-deception that believes the lie. That phrase from the Rodgers and Hart song I Wish I Were in Love again distills the theme of Marguerite, Xavier Giannolis satirical comedy about a tone-deaf would-be opera diva who thinks she can sing.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for March 11-17
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for March 11-17
description: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

title: Review: Molly Poerstel Challenges Structure at Gibney Dance
description: A row of pillars runs down the center of the studio-theater at Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center. Any choreographer presenting work there has to solve this architectural problem, and while it sometimes proves cumbersome, Molly Poerstel has made it work to her advantage.

title: Review: In Me Him Her, Late-20-Somethings Emerge From Lifes Confusion
description: The screenwriter and director Max Landis  he wrote the recent action-comedy-horror-thriller mash-ups American Ultra and Victor Frankenstein  is the son of John Landis. You can see the elder Landiss touch in Max Landiss first feature as a director, Me Him Her. But its not Animal House that shows up.

title: Theater Listings for March 11-17
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for March 11-17
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Mourning Nancy Reagan, and Looking Back at the Class and Dignity of an Era
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  In death, Nancy Reagan is drawing the kind of public warmth and adulation that her husband received for much of his life.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, March 12 Through 27
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Van Dyck at the Frick, Documenting Aristocracy
description: The synchronization of art, talent, money and power is a constant that was especially clear-cut in the 17th and 18th centuries, when kings were still considered semi-divine and the camera was not yet invented. This gave skilled portrait painters a signal importance. They produced likenesses  generally flattering  that affirmed the status of rulers and nobles for one another, their constituencies and posterity.

title: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Draw Distinctions on Immigration Policy
description: Join us for live updates of the Republican debate.

title: Spare Times Listings for March 11-17
description: American Museum of Natural History: Countdown to Zero (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.

title: Movie Listings for March 11-17
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Dance Listings for March 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Justin Trudeau, European Central Bank
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Classical Music Listings for March 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: TransCanada Is Said to Show Interest in Buying Columbia Pipeline
description: TransCanada Corporations request to build an oil pipeline through the United States was denied recently. So the company sought to buy its way into the region instead.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for March 11-17
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Highlights From Asia Week
description: Asia Week, the 10-day parade of exhibitions that arrives each spring from every corner of that continent, can seem like a parallel universe to the art world most often written about here.

title: Review: Joan Osborne Delivers No-Nonsense Dylan
description: Well, it may be the Devil or it may be the Lord/But youre gonna have to serve somebody.

title: For St. Patricks Day Parade 1855, Snow on the Clover
description: Who marches, and who doesnt. That is the perennial talk of the latter-day St. Patricks Day Parade in New York. Mayor Bill de Blasio will march this year. As will a group representing gay Irish-Americans.

title: Review: Brian Fallon Strikes Out on His Own With the Same Raspy Zeal for Yesteryear
description: With Brian Fallons voice, the decay is the thing. Pockmarked and abraded but still firm, its a vehicle for beautiful distress, for committed uncertainty. Over the last decade, primarily as the frontman for the Gaslight Anthem, hes become a vessel for preserving some of the best bits of American rock, especially from the 1950s and 1970s, and also a singular nostalgist with a gift for lyrics that evoke a non-idyllic past without living in it.

title: Jazz Listings for March 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Ben Carson to Endorse Donald Trump
description: Join us for live updates of the Republican debate.

title: House of Cards Season 4, Episode 10: The Sympathy Vote
description: The specter of death seeps into every story line in this chapter of House of Cards. Claires mother, Elizabeth Hale, passes away. Frank makes a confession to Cathy Durant that for a moment feels as shocking as the final scene of The Jinx. Yet as sad and macabre as things get, everything still works out for the Underwoods. Frank is officially chosen as the Democratic presidential candidate, and Claire  who picks up some sympathy votes in the wake of her recent loss  is officially named her husbands running mate. It seemed as if it couldnt be done, mainly because it still doesnt make much sense. But apparently, all a first lady needs to shatter political conventions and logic is a little help from the Grim Reaper.

title: This Weeks Movies | March 11, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review The Brothers Grimsby, Eye in the Sky and 10 Cloverfield Lane.

title: Nefertiti 3-D Scanning Project in Germany Raises Doubts
description: BERLIN  Experts have raised questions about assertions by two German artists that they used a concealed mobile device to scan the bust of Queen Nefertiti at the Neues Museum in Berlin, and then released the resulting data online in a project meant to question museum policies and notions of cultural ownership.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Weird at Paris Fashion Week
description: This years Paris Fashion Week was an unusual one: two major houses, Dior and Lanvin, were without creative directors; rumors swirled about Phoebe Philos departure from Cline; a new designer debuted at the storied Balenciaga; and Hedi Slimane, who many suspect will soon leave Saint Laurent, presented a show entirely different from his past ready-to-wear collections for the label. Against this backdrop, there were the expected shenanigans: Rei Kawakubo imagined an 18th-century punk; Kendall Jenner and Gigi Hadid switched hair colors; and Kanye West tried to blend in while wearing a pearl-covered jacket.

title: Brazil Prosecutors Seek Arrest of Lula, Former President, in Graft Case
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Prosecutors in Brazil are seeking the arrest of the countrys former president, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, by far the biggest figure to be ensnared by the sweeping corruption investigations that have upended the nation and rattled almost every level of government.

title: Health Officials Urge Congress to Fund Zika Research
description: The nations top health officials said Thursday that urgent action was needed to contain the Zika virus and appealed to Congress to allocate money to fighting the outbreak.

title: New Yorks Yiddish Theater Explores a Fractious Heritage of Melodrama and Musicals
description: A DEFINITE if wobbly line connects the Yiddish theater of 19th-century Eastern Europe and the Lower East Side to the giants of modern American entertainment. It traces a long road from the ghettos and shtetls to Broadway and Hollywood and the likes of Marlon Brando and Barbra Streisand.

title: Movie Review: The Brothers Grimsby
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Brothers Grimsby.

title: Greece and More  Photos of the Day
description: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere

title: March 10, 2016  Photos of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, Japan, India and Syria.

title: Where to Go in Bentonville, Arkansas
description: A Frank Lloyd Wright house intensifies the cultural traffic in an Arkansas city known mostly as the headquarters of Walmart.

title: Movie Review: 10 Cloverfield Lane
description: The Times critic Jeannette Catsoulis reviews 10 Cloverfield Lane.

title: Movie Review: Eye in the Sky
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Eye in the Sky.

title: PMK-BNC Absorbs the Boutique Publicity Agency Prime
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood publicity and marketing agency PMK-BNC absorbed the clients and principals of a smaller competitor on Thursday, sending a ripple through a corner of moviedom that has been relatively quiet of late.

title: 7 Democrats in Congress Say Clinton Email Inquiry Is Too Politicized
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Democrats in Congress have accused the inspectors general of the State Department and the nations intelligence agencies of politicizing their review of Hillary Clintons use of a private email server while she was secretary of state.

title: Republican Threats and the Supreme Court
description: On Monday, John Cornyn, the senior Republican senator from Texas, warned President Obama that if he dares to name a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court, the nominee will bear some resemblance to a piata.

title: Bill Gadsby, N.H.L. Star With Scars to Prove It, Dies at 88
description: Bill Gadsby was 12 years old and crossing the Atlantic with his mother on the British ocean liner Athenia at the outset of World War II when it was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine. They spent several hours in a lifeboat before being rescued.

title: Effects of Meldonium on Athletes Are Hazy
description: The drug that caused Maria Sharapovas failed doping test sounds almost like a miracle potion.

title: 12th Republican Debate: Analysis
In Tsunamis Wake, a Japanese Family Drifts Apart
description: After the tsunamis dark waves receded from the Japanese city of Kesen, leaving destruction in their wake, the Satos huddled together on what remained of their family plot. Naoshi and Teruko Satos son, Shoichi, a firefighter who had raced toward the sea to rescue the stranded, was missing. Shoichis wife, Mio Sato, was sick with worry.

title: The Speech Yang Jisheng, Barred From Going to U.S., Planned to Give at Harvard
description: In China, as in other countries ruled by authoritarian regimes, journalists and authors intent on exposing wrongdoing and telling the truth inevitably find themselves at odds with the government. Such is the case with Yang Jisheng, a longtime reporter for the state news agency Xinhua who, after he retired, published a landmark book, Tombstone, documenting the deaths of 36 million people during the 1958-62 famine, one of the worst man-made disasters in history.

title: Officer in Fatal Shooting of Ramarley Graham Faces Police Dept. Charges
description: After federal prosecutors declined this week to file criminal charges against a white New York City police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager in the Bronx four years ago, the Police Departments long-delayed internal case against him will proceed.

title: In Tsunamis Wake, a Japanese Family Drifts Apart
description: In the five years after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, Hiroko Masuike has followed the Sato family, whose members drifted apart as they struggled to recover and rebuild.

title: For Hedge Funds, Start of 2016 Offers Little Relief From 2015
description: The hedge fund titan Larry Robbins did something out of character last year. He apologized to investors for losing their money and pledged to right the ship as quickly as possible. Then he solicited more money from them, raising $1 billion for a new fund and promised to waive the fees.

title: Long Island Teenager Pleads Guilty in Deadly Drag-Racing Crash
description: A Long Island teenager pleaded guilty on Thursday to more than a dozen criminal charges stemming from a 2014 street-racing crash that left five other teenagers dead, prosecutors said. He is likely to be sentenced to six months in jail under an agreement.

title: Sharapova Is Not the Only Player Paying Little Attention to Antidoping Emails
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Explaining on Monday how she tested positive for the recently banned substance meldonium, Maria Sharapova admitted that she received an email from the World Anti-Doping Agency in December that contained changes in its prohibited list. The list included meldonium.

title: Muslims Sue Over Denial of Bid to Build Mosque in New Jersey Suburb
description: In a prosperous New Jersey suburb about an hour west of Manhattan, a retired AT&T executive decided with some friends to open a mosque in the town where he has lived for nearly 40 years, been on the board of education, led a task force to create the towns community center and even served as mayor.

title: Complaint in Basking Ridge Mosque Case
description: The Islamic Society of Basking Ridge argues that the Township of Bernards, N.J., and others have blocked the construction of a mosque by raising unreasonable objections and devising a "Kafkaesque" approval process.

title: At Pepes Place, a Chef With a Flavorful Past Creates Soul Food
description: Pepe Manigault said there were two reasons he decided to showcase seafood at Pepes Place, his small cafe in New Rochelle.

title: What You Missed in the Debate
description: Heres how we analyzed the Republican debate.

title: Review: Taino Smokehouse and Its Hodgepodge of Barbecue
description: Five years ago Chris Szewczyk quit a successful career as a software engineer, abandoning his office cubicle to follow the lure of barbecue. The restaurant he and his wife, Jenny, opened in 2012, Taino Smokehouse in Middletown, adjoining the Ace Hardware store, isnt much bigger than a cubicle. Its tiny kitchen barely holds the restaurants Ole Hickory Pits smoker, and its cozy dining area has just seven tables. The walls are painted a reddish brown, between black wainscoting below and black ceiling above, so the room itself looks, vaguely, suitably charred; a big overhead fan lazily pushing smoky air around adds to the effect.

title: Jets Build Running Corps, but Still Lack a Quarterback
description: In the first two days of free agency, the Jets secured their top three running backs for next season  Matt Forte, Bilal Powell and Khiry Robinson. They had yet to determine by Thursday who would be handing the ball off to them.

title: Review: At Industry Standard, Pub Fare That Gets a Little Adventurous
description: The formula for the contemporary gastro pub is pretty basic: Offer an alternative to chains like T.G.I. Fridays by being distinct and idiosyncratic. This includes dcor that reflects a personality or a region, a beer and wine selection that embraces local artisans whenever possible, and simple but good food that does not arrive in microwaveable bags trucked in from central headquarters.

title: Review: Vital, in Montclair, Whisks Diners to the Caribbean
description: Im not partial to Caribbean food but after several visits to Vital in Montclair, I fell in love with it. And Im not alone. Everyone I brought into the bright and festive restaurant on a busy stretch of Bloomfield Avenue was also smitten. The laid-back atmosphere is one reason; the large, colorful room accented with green walls and turquoise cloth napkins radiates that incongruous mix of luxury and insouciance that distinguishes the best Caribbean resorts. Its funky in the nicest possible way.

title: Documenting Violence Against Women, Even if Its Hard to Look
description: The doors to a small but powerful new exhibition at the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center of Nassau County in Glen Cove are usually kept closed.

title: Clyde Lovellette, Hall of Famer Who Brought Size and Skill to Basketball, Dies at 86
description: Clyde Lovellette, a bruising Hall of Famer who was one of the first big men in basketball and the first player to win an N.C.A.A. championship, an Olympic gold medal and an N.B.A. title, died on Wednesday at his home in North Manchester, Ind. He was 86.

title: White House Welcomes Canadas First Family
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau made the first official visit to the White House by a Canadian leader in 19 years.

title: Amid Conflict, Rutgers Acquires a Noted Filmmaker
description: Aspiring artists who enroll at Rutgers University do not lack for accomplished role models.

title: Poets Give Voice to Art in Sound and Sense at Wadsworth Museum
description: Go ahead and recite the verses that accompany the artwork in Sound and Sense: Poetic Musings in American Art, at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art. Feel the pulsing rhythms, like soldiers marching or the relentless ticking of a clock. Listen to the passion: the exuberance of love, the wonderment of nature, the sorrow of loss. Delight in the play of words: Goosey goosey gander / Whither shall I wander? / Upstairs and downstairs / And in my ladys chamber.

title: At the Jay Heritage Center in Rye: Young Americans
description: If you like a sprawling, multifaceted plotline when it comes to cultural experiences, incorporating watershed moments in United States history, architecture, landscape design and the abolitionist movement, put the Jay Heritage Center in Rye on your list of destinations.

title: N.J. Transit Labor Talks Resume, but No Deal Is Reached
description: With two days left before New Jersey Transit rail workers could go on strike, negotiators from the agency and its rail unions met again on Thursday but did not reach an agreement.

title: Wounded Warrior Projects Board Fires Top Two Executives
description: The Wounded Warrior Project ousted its top two executives Thursday after accusations of lavish spending and financial irregularities by the charity.

title: Justin Trudeaus White House Dinner Has the Air of a Family Reunion
description: WASHINGTON  When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada mounted the carpeted steps of the White Houses North Portico on Thursday night for one of this citys most glamorous rituals, a state dinner, he followed in his fathers footsteps  but only so far.

title: At Garden, Top Big East Seeds Try Out Knicks Quarters
description: When he popped into the training room adjacent to the Knicks locker room before Villanovas quarterfinal game Thursday against Georgetown, Wildcats guard Josh Hart could hardly believe his eyes.

title: Michael White, Colorful Impresario With a Taste for the Outlandish, Dies at 80
description: Michael White, a Scottish-born theater and movie producer whose catholic but often risqu taste and devil-may-care attitude helped bring to life The Rocky Horror Show, Oh! Calcutta! and Monty Python and the Holy Grail, died on Monday. He was 80.

title: This Is a Hockey School: Quinnipiac Students and Polls Agree
description: HAMDEN, Conn.  Goaltender Michael Garteig knows it takes 66 hours to drive the 3,000-plus miles to the Quinnipiac University campus from his hometown, Prince George, British Columbia, because he has taken that long journey all by himself.

title: Riskiest Political Act of 2016? Protesting at Rallies for Donald Trump
description: When Kashiya Nwanguma learned that Donald J. Trump would campaign in Louisville, Ky., where she is a student, she walked into a FedEx store and printed two colorful signs she had found online, depicting his head on a pigs body.

title: Suspended Aroldis Chapman Confident Despite Shaky Debut
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Sometime this season, when Aroldis Chapman, baseballs hardest thrower, confronts the heart of the Toronto Blue Jays fearsome batting order, the atmosphere will be different from that of Thursday, when a few thousand fans enjoyed a trifling spring training game.

title: Chile Halts Inquiry on American Who Disappeared 31 Years Ago
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Boris Weisfeiler, a mathematics professor at Penn State, liked to hike alone. A naturalized American citizen who immigrated from the Soviet Union in 1975, he had explored remote parts of Siberia, Alaska, Canada and Peru. On Dec. 24, 1984, Mr. Weisfeiler embarked on a hiking tour of southern Chile while the country was under military rule.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Exonerated After 25 Years in Prison for Murder
description: When police officers came upon the body of Neda Mae Carter in a park in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, 25 years ago, her face and neck were battered, her arms splayed and her legs straight, in the pose of a crucifixion.

title: Architecture of the Plain
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I suppose the Friday puzzle, compared to Thursday, is a bit like pure vs. applied science.

title: Review: In Boy, a Man Deals With Gender Cards Hes Given (Not Born With)
description: Bobby Steggert is a good little girl. Let me clarify: In the title role of Boy, the diligent new play by Anna Ziegler that opened on Thursday night at the Clurman Theater at Theater Row, Mr. Steggert is very good at portraying a little girl who wants to be good but is thwarted by the discomfort that comes from being born a boy, a fact of which she (he) is unaware.

title: Review: Blackbird: The Past Returns, Taunting
description: They make an alarming entrance, these two, setting off instant worry and wonder. They walk as if welded together, though whether in support, restraint or combat is unclear. Her eyes are wild and her bare legs wobbly, and he leads their stuttering steps with an angry, obdurate chin.

title: In Republican Debate, Candidates Lower Volume as 5 Key Primaries Near
description: MIAMI  Get live updates about voting in the Florida primary.

title: Analysis of the G.O.P. Debate in Florida
description: Nick Corasaniti of The Times points out key moments from the Republican presidential debate on Thursday in Coral Gables, Fla., where candidates discussed Cuba, immigration and climate change.

title: Two Shots at a Title
description: Quinnipiacs highly ranked mens and womens hockey teams, whose programs are not that old, both have a chance to win national championships.

title: Which Issues Each Party Debates, or Ignores
description: Democrats and Republicans sometimes seem to be living in two different Americas. We analyzed the past seven debates on each side to show which topics are most discussed within each party.

title: Iran Executions at Highest Level Since 89
description: Executions in Iran surged to nearly 1,000 in 2015, a United Nations investigator said on Thursday, the highest level in more than a quarter-century.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | acrimonious
description: acrimonious \a-kr-mo-ne-s\ adjective

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The works not hard, if you dont think about radiation.

title: Judge Declines to Reopen Case Against Ex-President Kirchner of Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES  A federal judge on Thursday refused to reopen a criminal complaint against former President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner first brought by a prosecutor who died in mysterious circumstances last year, according to Tlam, the state news agency.

title: Charles Granby, Who Coached Future N.B.A. Players in Queens, Dies at 81
description: Charles Granby, a renowned New York City basketball coach who amassed 722 victories over 45 years at the same Queens high school, coached a number of future N.B.A. players and served as a father figure for hundreds of young men, died on March 1 in Queens. He was 81.

title: Transcript of the Republican Presidential Debate in Florida
description: Following is a transcript of the Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: What to Watch Friday
description: Pixels, a nostalgia-fueled comedy starring Adam Sandler, is on Starz. ABC News tells the stories of families struggling with heroin addiction. And Bosch returns to Amazon for a second season of old-fashioned California noir.

title: Fact Check: Florida Republican Debate
description: The New York Times checks assertions made by the Republican presidential candidates during Thursday's debate in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Who Won the Debate? Substance Over Theater
description: The Republican presidential candidates turned to substance over theatrics on Thursday night in a final effort to court voters before they go to the polls in Florida, Ohio and three other states next week, in what could be a decisive Primary Day. There was little sparring and only a few barbs as the contenders largely stuck to talk of trade, terrorism and immigration. Commentators and critics thought a low-energy Donald J. Trump seemed to be running out the clock, while Senator Marco Rubio delivered a sharp performance that probably came too late.

title: North Korea: New Nuclear Threat
description: North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered his country to conduct more nuclear tests, its state media reported on Friday, while a senior United States military commander, Adm. William E. Gortney, warned during a Congressional hearing that the North had the ability to launch an intercontinental ballistic missile to the United States. The United States and South Korea began large-scale annual joint military exercises this week. Such drills typically prompt the North to issue bellicose warnings.

title: Corrections: March 11, 2016
description: NATIONAL

title: Dogs, Cats and Leadership
description: When he was in the middle of his Syrian peace deal negotiations, Secretary of State John Kerry would go to President Obama with a request: Could the U.S. quietly send a few cruise missiles to hit Assad regime targets, just to send a message and maybe move the Syrian president toward a deal.

title: Trade and Tribulation
description: Why did Bernie Sanders win a narrow victory in Michigan, when polls showed Hillary Clinton with a huge lead? Nobody really knows, but theres a lot of speculation that Mr. Sanders may have gained traction by hammering on the evils of trade agreements. Meanwhile, Donald Trump, while directing most of his fire against immigrants, has also been bashing the supposedly unfair trading practices of China and other nations.

title: Irish Spring
description: Between the Guinness and the leprechauns, the rivers of green and the buckets of blarney, were going to experience a lot of paddywhackery over the next week. Patricks high holiday, honoring the Roman British outcast who never drove the snakes from Ireland, may generate more than the usual excess of Celtic pride.

title: Fill In the Foreign Policy Blanks
description: The next president will have to set the direction of the fight against terrorism, define Americas role in the Syrian war, which has created a refugee crisis that is destabilizing Europe, and address the tensions between China and its neighbors that could turn into military conflict.

title: What Are Trump Fans Really Afraid to Say?
description: RHINESTONES twinkling around the perimeter of her shades, cornsilk curls undaunted by the Pensacola sun, Elizabeth Kemper, a supporter of Donald J. Trump, is all certainty. She is fed up. You know, this country is so dang political correct, she tells a CNN reporter. Im afraid to say what I really feel, you know?

title: New York Challenges a Tax Privilege of the Rich
description: Two Democratic members of the New York State Assembly, Jeffrion Aubry and Sean Ryan, introduced a bill this week to close the carried interest loophole, which lets partners at private equity firms and hedge funds pay a greatly reduced federal tax rate on much of their income.

title: What Liberals Can Learn From the N.R.A.
description: VILIFYING the National Rifle Associations tactics has long been standard practice among liberals. In October, Hillary Clinton compared dealing with the N.R.A. to negotiating with the Iranians or the Communists. In January, President Obama accused the gun lobby of holding Congress hostage. The New York Daily News recently called Wayne LaPierre, the N.R.A.s chief executive, a terrorist.

title: A Global Barbie Moment
description: The doll beloved by generations of girls is having a moment among the masters this year, with a flurry of international museum shows.

title: With Museum Shows in Europe, Barbie Gets Her Moment With the Masters
description: MILAN  When the Museum of Cultures opened here late last year, banners on its facade in the Tortona district announced coming marquee exhibitions: Gauguin, Mir  and Barbie.

title: Donald Trump Criticized After Calling Tiananmen Protests a Riot
description: HONG KONG  During the Republican presidential debate on Thursday, Donald J. Trump was forced to defend his earlier comments about the Chinese governments 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen protests in Beijing. He said that he did not endorse the crackdown, which he called horrible. But critics pointed out that in his comments on Thursday he called the protests a riot, which matches the Chinese governments description of the events.

title: News Qs | Class Differences in Child Rearing Are on the Rise
description: The following lesson activities are based on the article Class Differences in Child Rearing Are on the Rise.

title: Mass Rape, a Weapon of War, Traumatizes South Sudan
description: GENEVA  First they killed her husband. Then, the South Sudanese woman said, government soldiers tied her to a tree and forced her to watch as at least 10 of them raped her 15-year-old daughter.

title: Nancy Reagan: Her Most Memorable Moments
description: Nancy Reagan, who died March 6, was a socialite, onetime actress and behind-the-scenes influence. As first lady, she was best known for her devotion to both her husband and his policies. Here are some archived moments in the life of the woman behind the man.

title: In the Waiting Room of Estranged Spouses
description: I Googled counseling and scrolled through pages of possibilities before finally settling on a female psychologist with a kind face. Later that week, I went to her office wanting to talk about fidelity and broken trust, but somehow we ended up talking about sex and guilt. I cried a lot.

title: He Abused Her for Years. She Shot Him. France Asks: Is It Self-Defense?
description: LA SELLE-SUR-LE-BIED, France  Jacqueline Sauvage and Norbert Marot married as teenagers and built their dream house of wood and stone with a big garden and terrace in this village 70 miles south of Paris.

title: Filmed in New York, Starring My Home
description: Standing on a leafy Brooklyn block in the 2015 film The Intern, Anne Hathaway gazes at the handsome brownstone where her character lives, turns to Robert De Niro and says: I love this house. It just looks happy to me.

title: Growing Up Together
description: He tripped her in high school, but she had already fallen for him a year before.

description: When Ricky Phung tried to get Sharon Zhens attention by tripping her in the ninth grade at San Gabriel High School in California, he was unaware that she had already fallen for him.

description: It was a restrained, PG-rated debate in a primary campaign drenched in vulgarity and rhetorical bile. But in the last forum before the critical primaries in Florida and Ohio, the Republican presidential contenders all gave powerful signals of where their candidacies are headed.

description: Question:

title: Morning Agenda: Hedge Funds Make a Poor Start to the Year
description: HEDGE FUNDS MAKE A POOR START TO THE YEAR | Last year was tough for hedge fund managers, but this year is starting to look just as bad and investors are finding it hard to stomach,Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson report in DealBook.

title: This Weeks Other Solar Eclipse
description: Wednesdays solar spectacle over the Pacific Ocean wasnt the only eclipse to happen this week. More than 22,000 miles above Earth, NASAs Solar Dynamics Observatory, or SDO, watched the sun blackout every day for nearly a month.

title: Obama Is Eager to Nominate a Justice, but Timeline Is Unclear
description: Senate Democrats are eager for President Obama to announce his choice for the Supreme Court and to put a human face on their battle with Senate Republicans over filling the vacancy. And Mr. Obama said on Thursday that he thought it was important for me to nominate a Supreme Court nominee quickly because I think its important for the Supreme Court to have its full complement of judges.

title: New Yorks Week in Pictures: March 11
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from preparations for a rail workers strike in New Jersey.

description: Updated, 8:53 a.m.

title: Dancing Granny Is Shot, but Dont Expect the Music to Stop
description: BEIJING  With the din they make, they are often mocked and berated and worse. Dogs have been loosed on them. Rocks flung, water sprayed.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: That Family Party Everyone Hated? It Was Mine.
description: For years my husband and I threw a Christmas Eve party that was completely out of control: Friends brought their friends, and those friends brought their entire families. I never knew who was coming or how many of them there would be. Every year the house was packed with people Id never seen before. I found them sitting on the couch in my study with the door closed. I found them in the basement. Finally I changed the rules: Only family was invited.

title: In Republican Debate, Donald Trump Looks to Run Out the Clock
description: There are any number of sports metaphors that could be applied to the type of game Donald J. Trump was playing at the 12th Republican primary debate on Thursday night. Whether you call it running out the clock, playing keep-away or working the pitchers count, Mr. Trump was looking to escape the last face-off before the March 15 states hold their primaries having done as little harm to himself as possible.

title: How Gwyneth Paltrow Likes to Travel
description: Its not just about conscious uncoupling and recipes for superpowered avocado toast.

title: At Trump University, Students Recall Pressure to Give Positive Reviews
description: Robert Guillo gave a glowing evaluation to his instructor at Trump University because, he said, the teacher pleaded for the best possible score, warning that without it, Mr. Trump might not invite me back to teach again.

title: The Unnatural Kingdom
description: IF you ever have the good fortune to see a Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep, the experience might go like this: On a sunny morning in Yosemite National Park, you walk through alpine meadows and then up a ridge to the summit of Mount Gibbs at 12,764 feet above sea level. You unwrap a chocolate bar amid breathtaking views of mountain and desert and then you notice movement below.

title: A Jewelry Designer Draws Inspiration From Peggy Guggenheim
description: In the 1920s, the American heiress Peggy Guggenheim plunged into the bohemian swirl of Paris, where she stayed on and off for two decades, acquiring artist lovers and their paintings with equal gusto. And this week she returned  at least in spirit.

title: State Dinner Becomes a Catwalk for Canadian Style
description: After New York, London, Milan and Paris  Toronto? Long overlooked by the fashion folk, Canadian designers were front and center at the state dinner in the White House on Thursday night, as modeled by both Sophie Grgoire Trudeau, wife of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, and Michelle Obama.

title: Nature Plays a Tough Game
Smugglers Prey on Migrants Desperate to Find Back Doors to Europe
description: ATHENS  Shortly after landing on the Greek island of Lesbos in a waterlogged dinghy from Turkey, Rahin Salami, an Afghan hoping to reach Germany, boarded a ferry for the port of Piraeus, near Athens. Halfway through the ride, he later recounted, a man in a black jacket approached.

title: A Flexible Spending Account Deadline May Be Near
description: CONSUMERS who have a flexible health care spending account at work need to double-check their employers rules to see if they have an important deadline coming up.

title: As India Collaborates With Japan on Islands, It Looks to Check China
description: PORT BLAIR, India  India and Japan are in talks to collaborate on upgrading civilian infrastructure in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, an Indian archipelago seen as a critical asset to counter Chinas efforts to expand its maritime reach into the Indian Ocean.

title: Controlling Steam Radiators
description: While studying for his Ph.D. in electrical engineering at Columbia University six or seven years ago, Marshall Cox regulated his rooms temperature in winter the way most New Yorkers with steam radiators do. He opened a window.

title: Springs New Boxy (and Ladylike) Bags
description: Being square never looked so good.

title: Maria Sharapova and the Pharmaceutical Quest for an Edge
description: Its understandable that athletes at the highest end of the performance spectrum might look for any gain, any edge at all, that might help propel them to the top. Ego, fame and unbelievable amounts of money are at stake. But people all over the athletic spectrum are convinced that one supplement or another will make them healthier, faster or stronger, while other people seek a different sort of edge with drugs they hope will improve cognition.

title: 1941: Roosevelt Signs Lend-Lease Bill
description: President Roosevelt, at 3:50 oclock this afternoon, signed into law his historic lend-lease bill to aid Great Britain by turning the United States into an arsenal for democracy. Five minutes later, acting under the broad powers granted to him by the unprecedented peace-time legislation, the President signed orders for the immediate transfer to Britain of an undisclosed amount of Army and Navy equipment  warships, warplanes and general military supplies. Embattled Greece received lesser assistance, and struggling China is to be aided soon.

title: China Wrestles With Draft Law on Nongovernmental Organizations
description: BEIJING  It has been more than two years since the Chinese government proposed tighter controls on foreign nongovernmental organizations, prompting fears for the future of a wide range of groups active in China, like medical charities, branches of foreign universities and business chambers. Among their concerns are the prospect of requirements to obtain government sponsors and police approval of projects and restrictions on fund-raising.

title: Ben Carson Endorses Donald Trump, Saying We Buried the Hatchet
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Ben Carson, the retired pediatric neurosurgeon who ended his own presidential bid last week, endorsed Donald J. Trump at a news conference on Friday at Mar-a-Lago, Mr. Trumps club, calling him actually a very intelligent man who cares deeply about America.

title: For LeBron James and the Cavaliers, First Place Isnt Good Enough
description: LOS ANGELES  There was singing inside the Cleveland Cavaliers locker room late Thursday night.

title: The Style of Bouchra Jarrar
description: The designer, who opened her own brand in 2010, has been one of the few independent female designers working in Paris.

title: Lanvin Names Bouchra Jarrar as Artistic Director of Womens Collections
description: A woman is once again at the helm of the house Jeanne Lanvin built. On Friday morning, the Lanvin chief executive Michle Huiban confirmed that Bouchra Jarrar had been named artistic director of womens collections. She begins Monday.

title: Stephen Greenblatt Wins Holberg Prize
description: Stephen Greenblatt, the Harvard literary scholar best known for his studies of Shakespeare, has won Norways 4.5-million kroner (about $531,000) Holberg Prize, which is awarded annually to scholars who have made outstanding contributions to research in the arts, humanities, the social sciences, law or theology.

title: Once Hopeful for Harmony, a Philosopher Voices Discord in France
description: PARIS  He is the intellectual much of the French left loves to hate, the writer whose rumpled look has racked up multiple magazine covers, the bookish essayist turned omnipresent media star and boogeyman for proselytizers of painless multiculturalism. Alain Finkielkrauts mere presence in a television studio raises temperatures and sends accusations of racism flying.

title: Janet King, a Legal Drama Down Under
description: If weeknights have become an endless game of Name That S.V.U. Episode, Janet King may be your salvation. The Australian legal drama (beginning Monday, March 14, on the streaming service Acorn TV) stars Marta Dusseldorp in the title role, a senior crown prosecutor with a lacerating tongue and even sharper investigative skills who, on her first day back from maternity leave, is hurled into court to try a sexual predator. That case, though, is just the tip of a very deep iceberg exposed when a high-ranking police officer is charged with euthanizing his ailing wife, and Janet suspects murder. What follows as she connects the dots threatens to tear her relationship with her companion and their twins asunder  and possibly end her own life.  Ms. Dusseldorp has said that her role model was Helen Mirrens detective in Prime Suspect, for whom justice trumped likability. Bonus points: Ms. Dusseldorps aquiline profile and formidable stature are killer in the required court attire of wig, jabot and silk robe.

title: Profile in Style: Madeline Weinrib
description: The designer on life before her textile empire and how to have a unique aesthetic in the age of internet overload.

title: Pro-Democracy Nonprofit Is Banned in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A nonprofit group that promotes democracy has become the latest American-linked group to be banned in Russia under restrictions on undesirable organizations signed into law by President Vladimir V. Putin in May.

title: Slide Show: The Stylish Arrivals at the Obama-Trudeau State Dinner
description: Call it the other red carpet, without the carpet: Almost two weeks after awards season wrapped up, political, sports and Hollywood stars gathered at the White House on Thursday evening for one of the more glamorous political events of late, the state dinner for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and his wife, Sophie Grgoire Trudeau.

title: Making Technology Easier for Older People to Use
description: INTIMIDATED by digital technology? So was Marian Goldberg, 70, until she went to a Senior Planet Exploration Center in Manhattan, which teaches older adults how to become more comfortable being online.

title: Yale Rep to Debut Works by Amy Herzog and Sarah Ruhl

description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Aqua Capital, a private equity firm based in So Paulo, has raised $188 million for its second fund, according to two people briefed on its efforts.

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Get live updates about the Ohio primary.

title: Fall of the Pitchmen
description: They are part of our lives, ubiquitously appearing in 30-second blasts. Then the pitchmen just disappear. And with the retirement of the Most Interesting Man in the World, The Times presents a look at other bygone barkers.

title: Hillary Clinton Gets Some Star Power to Help in New Ads
description: CHICAGO  With just days before several primaries where she will depend on the loyalty of female and black voters in Florida, North Carolina and the Midwest, Hillary Clinton got some heavyweight help from Hollywood.

description: European Union leaders and Turkey reached a tentative deal this week to help stem the flow of migrants to the Continent.

title: Richard Linklater on Baseball, College Life and His New Film
description: In the 26 years Richard Linklater has been making movies, he has frequently returned to familiar territory. His Before films featured the same characters at different ages, and Boyhood was shot bit by bit annually over a dozen years. Mr. Linklater is clearly curious about the past and how it shapes his present.

title: Bank Employee Pleads Guilty to Conspiring to Work as Secret Russian Agent
description: Just weeks before he was to go on trial in federal court, a Russian bank employee in New York pleaded guilty on Friday to one count of conspiring to act as an unregistered Russian agent in the United States.

title: Hillary Clinton Urges Effort to Improve Struggling Schools
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Hillary Clinton made a pitch for public schools at a get-out-the-vote rally on Thursday, proposing to create a teaching task force that would recruit more young people and midcareer professionals to the countrys struggling public schools.

title: The Comic and the Ping-Pong Champ
description: In July, as a polite 26-year-old Chinese-born New Yorker named Wu Yue put together a string of table tennis victories at the Pan American Games in Toronto, the cheers from a bearded man wearing a trucker hat were impossible to ignore.

title: 1921 | Catching Einstein in an Error
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from New York Times journalists.

title: A Painter and a Poet Dream Up a Mighty Bull
description: For Ts ongoing series, the artist Not Vital responded to a poem by the writer Ocean Vuong, whose first full-length collection of poetry, Night Sky With Exit Wounds, comes out next month.

title: Eclectic Lineup Adds to Credibility of Red Bull Music Event
description: One of the advertising industrys favorite buzzwords is branded content, the idea that marketing messages can be conveyed with special subtlety through the guise of entertainment or even journalism. But the concept often falls flat, as readers see through awkward advertorials and as the logos of eager corporate sponsors overtake pop-culture events like South by Southwest.

title: Popcast: The Art and Future of Criticism
description: New York Times critics gather to discuss their newly released books.

title: 1966: Verdict in Malcolm Xs Killing
description: NEW YORK  All three defendants in the Malcolm X murder trial  two of them Black Muslims  were convicted of murder in the first degree early today [March 11]. Convicted were Talmadge Hayer, 24, also known as Thomas Hagan, of Paterson, N.J.; Norman 3X Butler, 27, and Thomas 15X Johnson, 30, both of the Bronx. Black nationalist leader Malcolm X, 39, was slain in a Manhattan ballroom, Feb. 21, 1965, before 400 of his followers.

title: English Rugby Teams Visiting U.S. (This Is Not an Exhibition)
description: Though soccer has broken through in recent years, many other international sports have remained a mystery to American fans. Part of this may be the complexity of the rules of games like cricket and snooker. The current hot talking point in rugby union is a dispute between the England and Wales teams over supposed illegal scrummaging. Not scrimmaging, scrummaging.

title: Popcast: Why Be a Critic?
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: For a Little While, by Rick Bass
description: Scientists say weve entered a new geological age, one they propose calling the Anthropocene owing to humanitys outsize effect on the environment. Theres little doubt to any observant person that were making a mess of things. Driving up Route 93 south of Florence, Mont., you can see the damage. Although the loggers quit clearcutting the mountains in the 1980s, the rest of us didnt stop superheating the planet. Now pine beetles, which flourish in our era of abbreviated winters, have left acres of dead ponderosa and lodgepole pines.

title: Paperback Row
description: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Editors Choice
description: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.

title: Inside the List
description: Lets Get Physical: If you believe Einstein, time as we usually understand it is nothing more than a persistent, stubborn illusion. That may be. But timing is still everything  and the timing could hardly be better for the theoretical physicist Carlo Rovellis latest book, Seven Brief Lessons on Physics, new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No.5. Originally published two years ago in Rovellis native Italy (where it outsold Fifty Shades of Grey), the book arrives in America less than a month after scientists announced the first direct evidence of gravitational waves, confirming Einsteins theory of general relativity and reigniting the publics occasional love affair with what may be the hardest of the hard sciences. (Over the years, other theoretical physicists to hit the list have included Stephen Hawking, Brian Greene, Lisa Randall and Lawrence Krauss.) Rovelli, as it happens, is an expert on gravity: Hes a founder of the loop quantum gravity theory, the chief competitor to string theory among efforts to unite the macro world of relativity with the micro world of quantum mechanics. So he was giddy at the news that gravitational waves had been detected. For physicists this is an ecstatic moment, he wrote on Slate. If a benign nature wanted to honor the centenary of Einsteins idea, she has found the most elegant way. Its hard to imagine a more vivid indication of the power of scientific reason: From indirect evidence and clarity of thought, reason sees so far that it takes another century before our eyes and our hands can follow up.

title: Anna and the Swallow Man, by Gavriel Savit
description: There are two questions about Gavriel Savits splendid debut novel that are sure to be asked repeatedly: Is it an allegory, and at whom is it aimed? The first I believe Savit answers clearly. The world understands stories, he has one of his main characters come to realize, not as absolute, irrevocably factual truths that simply dont exist, but as flaccid allegories or metaphors. You may read the novel as allegory; go ahead. All stories are allegory. This one makes use of stock figures from European folklore (the fool, the golem, the trickster, the demon, animal shape-changers). Its also tempting to expand on ways in which the novels characters represent aspects of the Polish people during World War II. Even the winsome chapter-heading designs created by the illustrator Laura Carlin can be interpreted in more than one way. But Anna and the Swallow Man, and the very human people they meet in the course of the novel, also have their own plausible existence within the rules of the world we know. Indeed, they learn to question and distrust allegory as the tale progresses. For every apparent piece of magic performed in the text, there is a scientific explanation. When the Swallow Man gives Anna a fantastical description of the medicine he takes, for example, there is a literal interpretation as well. This is masterly storytelling.

title: The Girl in the Well Is Me, by Karen Rivers
description: Anyone of a certain age remembers the little girl who fell into a well in Texas in the late 1980s. Workers spent three days trying to free her. It was the stuff of parent nightmares. Coming at the dawn of the 24-hour news cycle, the story was covered night and day, causing our child imaginations to go wild: Was she going to die? How did she go to the bathroom? The event was, of course, soon turned into a TV movie.

title: Forest of Wonders, by Linda Sue Park
description: It all seems innocent enough. The White Rabbit fretting about the time. Charlotte writing in her web. Pooh spouting his honey-sweet wisdom. The world of childrens literature is a veritable petting zoo, full of adorable talking animals ready to snuggle us to sleep.

title: Five Up and Coming Irish Designers to Know Right Now
description: Ireland is a country still best known for Waterford crystal, Belfast linen and Donegal tweed. But these days, talented designers there are working across all disciplines  from glass and ceramics to wood and textiles. Now, thanks to a concerted push by the Design & Crafts Council of Ireland, the wider world is catching on. This month the council is collaborating with Heals, a British furniture and furnishing brand with a flagship store on Londons Tottenham Court Road, to host Design Ireland, a pop-up market showcasing some of the hottest creative talent working in the Emerald Isle. Each maker combines traditional crafting techniques and skills with the highest-quality materials and fresh ideas, pushing the boundaries to produce contemporary, relevant objects for the home. There will also be a series of in-store demonstrations offering visitors an insight into the processes behind the craft. Here, we introduce five Irish makers to look out for.

title: Kafkas Odds and Ends
description: Kafka really didnt like mice. What a horrible silent noisy people they are, he wrote to a friend. My feeling toward the mice is flat-out fear, he explained to another. It has to do with the unexpected, unbidden, unavoidable, virtually silent, persistent, ulteriorly motivated appearance of these animals.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Bookshelf: Bedtime Adventures
description: New picture books include Shhh! I'm Sleeping and Blanche Hates the Night.

title: Innocents and Others, by Dana Spiotta
description: The literature of friendship, like friendship itself, tends to unfold episodically  with none of the narrative determination of the Marriage Plot, in which young women accrue interest like a mutual fund until they mature into the expected climax: not orgasm but matrimony. There is no such thing as the Friendship Plot, because while friendship, like marriage, is at least presumably a voluntary estate, it has no official consummation, no church- or state-sanctioned vows. It would seem, then, that the literary form most suited to its pick-up-where-we-left-off, drop-me-when-you-couple-up-and-have-kids ebb and flow might be the story cycle, or serial tale  just ask Quixote and Sancho, or Huck and Tom, or the four dudes of The Three Musketeers.

title: Political Cloud Relegates Marco Rubios Onetime Insider to the Outside
description: MIAMI  When Marco Rubio struggled to choose an engagement ring for his wife, his closest friend and unwavering political ally, David Rivera, was by his side. When all four of Mr. Rubios children were born, Mr. Rivera kept vigil in the waiting room.

title: Sudden Death, by lvaro Enrigue
description: lvaro Enrigue, a Mexican author who lives in New York, must be having some fun when people ask what his latest novel is about. In no particular order, Sudden Death concerns: the tale of four tennis balls made from the hair of a beheaded Anne Boleyn; a fictional tennis match between the Italian painter Caravaggio and the Spanish poet Francisco de Quevedo; Cortss conquest of Mexico; and the history of various ball games. It also includes a few emails purporting to be an exchange between the author and an editor in Spain, as well as references to Thomas Mores Utopia, Galileo and the Aztec emperor Cuauhtmoc. And theres a dialogue featuring Pope Pius IV. What isnt Enrigues novel about?

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a three-bedroom condo in New Canaan, Conn., and a five-bedroom house in Garden City, N.Y.

title: The Night Gardener, Tokyo Digs a Garden and Stories From Bug Garden
description: Spring is (almost) here. Its time to be thinking about your garden, if you have one. Even if you dont, thinking about gardens  renewal, growth, wildness, creativity  has its own reward. As three new picture books with dramatically varied styles of illustration show, a garden is an idea that can be approached from starkly different directions.

title: The Bronts
description: JANE STEELEA ConfessionBy Lyndsay Faye432 pp. Putnam, $27.

title: When Its Time to Buy Out Partners, but Money Is Tight
description: BRAD SACKS brought in two family friends who were older and wiser when he started his sauce company, More Than Gourmet, in 1993. They didnt invest any money, Mr. Sacks said, but for their help, he gave the men half of the company.

title: Drawing Inspiration
description: William Makepeace Thackeray may not be thought of as an artist, but he was a very fine one. He longed to illustrate Dickens, but when he was turned down he wrote his own novel, Vanity Fair, partly so he could illustrate it himself.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: How Wage Insurance Could Ease Economic Inequality
description: Wage insurance may not be on your radar, but it should be. It helps people who have lost their jobs and cannot find new ones that pay as well. That assistance can reduce economic inequality while providing incentives for unemployed people to go back to work quickly.

title: Tefaf Faces Competitive Headwinds
description: MAASTRICHT, The Netherlands  The European Fine Art Fair, held on the outskirts of this historic Dutch city, has for almost three decades been the worlds pre-eminent commercial event devoted to pre-21st-century art and objects.

title: Polands Government Is Accused of Violating Separation of Powers
description: WARSAW  Polands new right-wing government received a sharp rebuke on Friday from a European human rights group over its efforts to blunt the ability of the countrys constitutional court to rule on new laws.

title: Stock Buyback Plans, Seen as Shareholder Boon, Can Backfire
description: Stock buybacks are a boon for shareholders, right?

title: At a London Restaurant, More Than a French Accent
description: Britain and France may have a historically complicated relationship, but this has never stood in the way of their longstanding connection through fine dining.
