description: Winter isnt coming, its going, but the supermarkets are still loaded with cauliflower, and thats a depressing prospect. Some people love this albino broccoli, other people hate it, but no one thinks its very exciting.

title: Scorsese, De Niro and Co-Stars Reunite for Taxi Driver Screening
description: You talkin to me? Well Im the only one here, Robert De Niro, playing Travis Bickle, famously riffs in the mirror in Taxi Driver. Next month, many more will be listening when Mr. De Niro reunites with that 1976 films director, Martin Scorsese, its writer, Paul Schrader, and its co-stars Jodie Foster and Cybill Shepherd for a live conversation as part of the Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced on Friday.

title: European Union Reaches Deal With Turkey to Return New Asylum Seekers
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union has reached an agreement with Turkey that it hopes will ease the migrant crisis that has roiled the Continent for the past year.

title: First Woman Nominated to Lead U.S. Combatant Command
description: WASHINGTON  The White House will nominate Gen. Lori J. Robinson of the Air Force to lead all military forces in North America, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Friday. If confirmed by the Senate, General Robinson will become the first woman to head one of the United States combatant commands.

title: Inside the List
description: Heartburn: After two cookbooks and 11 seasons as the host of Top Chef on Bravo, Padma Lakshmi has earned the right to call herself a food expert. But that doesnt mean her relatives in India want her (or for that matter her aunt Neela, whos like a sister to Lakshmi) to cook for them. To this day, she writes in her memoir, Love, Loss, and What We Ate  new at No.14 on the hardcover nonfiction list  the elder women of my household in Chennai still regard Neela or me with suspicion whenever we enter the kitchen to make anything other than tea.

title: In Search of the Entry-Level Art Buyer
description: What happens next now that the latest art market boom has apparently slowed?

title: Banned in Beijing
description: RUINED CITYBy Jia PingwaTranslated by Howard Goldblatt520 pp. University of Oklahoma, paper, $24.95.

title: A Man Lies Dreaming, by Lavie Tidhar
description: A MAN LIES DREAMINGBy Lavie Tidhar307 pp. Melville House. $25.95.

title: Blood Brothers: The Fatal Friendship Between Muhammad Ali and Malcolm X
description: BLOOD BROTHERSThe Fatal Friendship Between Muhammad Ali and Malcolm XBy Randy Roberts and Johnny SmithIllustrated. 362 pp. Basic Books. $28.99.

title: Charlotte Bront: A Fiery Heart, by Claire Harman
description: CHARLOTTE BRONTA Fiery HeartBy Claire HarmanIllustrated. 462 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Linwood Barclays Far From True, and More
description: Miss Marples St. Mary Mead and Jessica Fletchers Cabot Cove are cautionary examples of quaint little villages that will eventually run out of murderers and victims. Promise Falls, one of the upstate New York hamlets where Linwood Barclay sets many of his books, is already dangerously close to losing its tax base. FAR FROM TRUE (New American Library, $27) continues to thin out the populace, but in a strikingly original way. A local landmark, the Constellation Drive-In Theater, is folding forever, and on its last, nostalgic night of business the four-story movie screen suddenly collapses, crushing two cars in the front row.

title: Carry Me, by Peter Behrens
description: CARRY MEBy Peter Behrens443 pp. Pantheon Books. $26.95.

title: The Road Taken, by Henry Petroski
description: THE ROAD TAKENThe History and Future of Americas InfrastructureBy Henry PetroskiIllustrated. 322 pp. Bloomsbury. $28.

title: Donald Trumps Rise Reverberates Around the World
description: Donald J. Trumps march toward the Republican presidential nomination has sent shock waves through American politics and, as he continued gobblingup delegates this week, the rest of the world has startedquivering, too.

title: Montclair Still Feels Strife From School Tests Posted Online in 13
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Serving subpoenas on public schoolteachers in class. Reading them their Miranda rights on school grounds. Using taxpayers money to hire investigators to search school employees computers late at night.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: American Eugenics
description: This week, Adam Cohen talks about Imbeciles; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ellen Fitzpatrick discusses The Highest Glass Ceiling; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: An Act of Courage in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Ts New Design Issue: The Material World
description: Sometimes we set out with the intention of putting T together along a conceptual theme, and at other times, like this one, a theme seems to emerge in the process of making the magazine  joining disparate-seeming stories to one another, and somehow reflecting our collective thinking about whats relevant and interesting at a given moment.

title: Insurance for Critical Illness May Add Security, but at a Cost
description: Its often pitched as an insurance policy for your health insurance policy.

title: Republicans Weak Opposition to Donald Trump
description: As the 2016 campaign limps through the primary season toward the national conventions, there are two mostly imaginary story lines that never fail to delight and amuse, even if they dont teach much.

title: Dalat, Vietnam
description: For our 52 Places to Go feature in January, we asked some of our photographers to shoot photo essays for the destinations they were covering. This is our first, on Dalat, Vietnam.

title: Former Affymetrix Executives Seek to Break Up Deal With Own Bid
description: Months after Affymetrix, a maker of advanced genetic analysis technology, agreed to sell itself for $1.3 billion, some of the companys former executives want to disrupt that deal  with the help of a Chinese financial backer.

title: Stroller Valet Service at a Park Slope Condo
description: Parents of young children rely on their strollers as if they were extensions of themselves. The stroller not only serves as a childs second home, it is also used as a grocery cart, a cup holder and a coat rack. But many are bulky and hard to store. They gobble space when parked by the doorway, or, to the dismay of those without children, in the hallways of residential buildings.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: The usual suspects

title: A $12.2 Million Condo for Katie Couric
description: Katie Couric and her husband of almost two years, the financier John P. Molner, bought an apartment on the entire 10th floor of 151 East 78th Street, a new limestone and brick condominium on the Upper East Side. At $12,168,087.50, the transaction was one of the most expensive sales of the week, according to city records.

title: No Texts, Please, Were Meditating
description: When a photo of a wall covered in lush green foliage showed up on Grace Clarkes Instagram feed, she felt an immediate urge to track it down. Stressed out and headed to a meeting at Madewell, where she works as a social media copy editor, Ms. Clarke saw that the walls location was on East Eighth Street in Manhattan at a meditation studio called MNDFL, which opened in November.

title: Mike Birbiglia Discusses Dont Think Twice at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Its a busy year for Mike Birbiglia. The comedian is currently onstage in New York in the one-man show Thank God for Jokes. But he took a short break from it earlier this week for a visit here to unveil a new movie, Dont Think Twice, in which he acts, and which he wrote and directed. That film follows a troupe of improv performers through their lives on and off the stage. The cast includes Keegan-Michael Key and Gillian Jacobs (as a couple who are part of the troupe), as well as Chris Gethard, Tami Sagher and Kate Micucci. In this video, Mr. Birbiglia speaks about the film and how he constructed its improv scenes.

title: A Park Avenue Duplex for $22.5 Million
description: The president of Vendome Press, a publishing house specializing in illustrated art and lifestyle books, is about to place on the market his longtime family home: a sprawling duplex at 720 Park Avenue, a neo-Georgian architectural gem designed by Rosario Candela in the late 1920s.

title: Alumni Discover Yales Basketball Team (and Theyre Charmed)
description: Elation and confusion are an unusual combination for victorious sports fans. But in New Haven and throughout the broader Yale community, the We won! euphoria of winning an N.C.A.A. tournament basketball game on Thursday quickly gave way to, What did we win, exactly? and Can someone explain why this basketball game was so important?

title: Defense Department Redefines Climate Change
description: So what does climate change mean, exactly?

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Queens
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in the Queens neighborhoods of Jackson Heights and Long Island City; and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Popcast: Gwen Stefani Returns
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Gwen Stefani on Spirituality, Insecurity, Pharrell and Truth
description: In the 10 years since Gwen Stefani last released a solo album, she has had two sons, returned to No Doubt, become a TV personality and watched as her life was literally blown up. In an interview at her Beverly Hills home for an in-depth feature article, Ms. Stefani, 46, spoke candidly (and plentifully) about the circumstances that led her to make her most personal album yet  This Is What the Truth Feels Like (Interscope), out Friday  and how spirituality and the guidance of Pharrell Williams have shaped her artistic process. These are edited excerpts from that conversation.

title: Sumner Redstones Medical Records to Stay Private, Judge Rules
description: The medical records of the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone will remain confidential, but some other court documents, including emails written by his nurses and a letter from Mr. Redstone to his daughter, Shari, will be made public, a California judge ruled on Friday.

title: Review: Krapps Last Tape, a Melancholy Tone Poem
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  This is not, for the record, the same old Krapp. The chalk-faced, squealing, macabre dandy who has materialized at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University bears scant resemblance to the classically grizzled figure weve come to associate with the title character of Krapps Last Tape, Samuel Becketts 1958 assessment of a life from the vantage point of its weary end.

title: Starwood Says Rivals Counteroffer Tops Bid from Marriott
description: Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide says a $13.2 billion takeover offer led by a Chinese insurer is superior to the one that was all but sealed by Marriott International  a deal that would have created the worlds largest hotel company.

title: Exclusive | 720 Park Avenue
description: A duplex in a neo-Georgian architectural gem designed by Rosario Candela in the late 1920s, is about to enter the market at $22.5 million.

title: The Indian Point Nuclear Plant
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for Marriott to Say Farewell to Starwood Deal
description: Its time for Marriott International to check out of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide.

title: Inside a Colombian Guerrilla Enclave
description: New York Times reporter Nicholas Casey makes a rare visit to a remote FARC camp as the rebels there await the outcome of peace talks in Havana.

title: A Rebel Hide-Out Deep in the Colombian Jungle
description: A sprawling camp in the Andes is home to about 150 members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC.

title: Steven Holls Design Chosen for Institute for Advanced Study
description: Steven Holl, the architect behind Princeton Universitys coming  Lewis Center for the Performing Arts, has another opportunity to make his mark on the New Jersey college town.

title: In a Rebel Camp in Colombia, Marx and Free Love Reign
description: IN THE MOUNTAINS OF COLOMBIA  The rebel camp is a Communist time capsule. An old guerrilla fighter sings songs about Che Guevara on his guitar as a crowd leans in to listen, armed with rifles and grenades.

title: Assault Charges Against Man Shot in Texas Hospital Are Dropped
description: Prosecutors have dropped assault charges against a college student with bipolar disorder who was shot in a Houston hospital room during a confrontation with two police officers moonlighting as security guards.

title: Influences: Book Award Winners in Their Own Words
description: Winners of the 2016 National Book Critics Circle Awards were asked what book or writer had the most profound influence on their work.

title: Twitter Rules Out Long Tweets, Sticking to 140-Character Limit
description: Two months ago, Twitters most dedicated fans threw a fit when news of a potentially major change in the service came to light: the 140-character limit, long one of Twitters defining characteristics, might be going away.

title: Better Relations With Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Protest Is Planned for Donald Trumps Speech Before Pro-Israel Group
description: Donald J. Trump could be staring at some empty seats when he comes to Washington on Monday to make a foreign affairs address before the American Israel Public Affairs Committees policy conference.

title: Sgt. Pepper Builds a Real-Life Chitty Chitty Bang Bang on Long Island
description: It is a well-known story: A quirky tinkerer rolls a rusted old car into his workshop, casts around for some parts, and emerges  honk, honk!  with a magical motorcar.

title: Steinhoff Drops Pursuit of Home Retail Group, Owner of Argos
description: LONDON  Steinhoff International Holdings of South Africa said on Friday that it had abandoned its pursuit of the Home Retail Group as a potentially lengthy bidding war loomed and instead agreed to acquire the French electronics and appliance retailer Darty.

title: How We Got to a Colombian Guerrilla Camp
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Nicholas Casey describes the path he took to meet the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.

title: A Democrat and a Republican, on the Choices We Face
description: To the Editor:

title: An Educated Guess on How Much Star Wars: The Force Awakens Will Make for Disney
description: Enormous attention is paid to box office results, in large part because of the lack of transparency at movie studios: There is no other publicly available financial data for films. Production costs? Reporters have to pry estimates out of sources. Marketing budgets? We dont discuss marketing, is the standard studio response.

title: Sexual Slavery: ISIS and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Senator Phil Gramm, a Former Marco Rubio Supporter, Backs Ted Cruz
description: Ted Cruz has earned a defector from the shuttered campaign of Marco Rubio: Phil Gramm, the former Texas senator once cited by Mr. Cruz as the senator I most admire.

title: Review: New York City Opera, a Quiet Sunday Morning
description: Sunday Morning, a work for soprano and small ensemble by the young composer David Hertzberg, was originally commissioned by Gotham Chamber Opera. But when that company foundered last year before a planned performance could take place, the piece was scooped up by New York City Opera, which was rising from the ashes of bankruptcy at just the same time.

title: U.S. Inquiry Into New Yorks Housing Authority Is Very Expansive, Its Chief Says
description: The leader of the New York City Housing Authority said on Friday that her staff had turned more than 400 million records over to federal prosecutors who are reviewing tenant health and safety conditions as they try to determine whether the agency filed false claims for federal funds to address any problems.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are four-bedroom homes in Wall Township, N.J. and Waccabuc, N.Y.

title: Beach House at Webster Hall: The Art of a Set List
description: The Baltimore dream-pop band Beach Houses sound thrives on repetition: lulling synthesizer drones, flowing guitar riffs and clipped phrases from the lead singer Victoria Legrand. But two Beach House shows will never be the same. The band switches up its setlist every night, pulling from all six of its albums and even asking for suggestions: Fans can submit three songs they most want to hear on the bands website.

title: Merrick Garland Battle Moves to Home Front as Senate Recesses
description: WASHINGTON  The fight over the vacancy on the Supreme Court shifted from close combat in the halls of Congress to a nationwide battle on Friday as senators returned to their home states for a two-week recess and Republican and Democratic leaders began aggressively making their cases in television and radio interviews, op-ed columns and public appearances.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: American Eugenics
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: The Nonsuch Dive
description: In the 1930s, two men in a bathysphere dove deeper  much deeper  in the ocean than anyone had before.

title: Basketball Primer for Yalies, From a Dukie: Its a Lot Like Squash
description: Greetings, Yalies!

title: Review: Max Reger, an Orphan-Composer Adopted for a Night
description: Describing his approach to programming before Thursdays concert by the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, the conductor Leon Botstein said, We deal in the purgatory department. Throughout history, he explained, some pieces seemed to go directly from their premieres to a lofty place in the heaven of the standard repertory. Others are consigned to hell.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Photos of the Day: Belgium and Elsewhere
description: Belgium and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Gay Man in Georgia Describes Attack With Scalding Water
description: A young gay man said he was struggling to recover from severe burns after a man poured scalding water on him and his boyfriend while they were asleep in an Atlanta-area apartment last month.

title: Examining Yiddish Theater, From Shtick to Stardom
description: During its New York heyday a century ago, the Yiddish theater, with its Shakespearean tragedies, tear-jerking melodramas and ludicrous comedies, was a proving ground from which some stars graduated to the borscht belt and beyond.

title: The Mourning Dove, a Melancholy Crooner
description: The song of the mourning dove is a melancholy counterpoint to the dazzling chorus of migrant bird calls now just beginning to fill the earliest spring air. At this time of year, even before the snow completely melts, resident doves  those that chose to take their chances on a mild New York City winter  begin their amorous cooing in sobering tones.

title: Warmer Winter Brings Forest-Threatening Beetles North
description: This winter has been the warmest on record in much of New England. And while many people enjoyed the T-shirt weather, it made Claire E. Rutledge, a researcher with Connecticuts Agricultural Experiment Station, more concerned about what next season may hold.

title: Mitt Romney Says Hell Vote for Ted Cruz in Utah Caucuses
description: Mitt Romney plans to vote for Senator Ted Cruz of Texas in Utahs caucuses on Tuesday, he wrote Friday in a Facebook post. He also seemed to call for Gov. John Kasich of Ohio to step aside to give Republicans a better chance to block Donald J. Trumps bid for the nomination.

title: March 18, 2016  Photos of the Day
description: Photos from Belgium, Ukraine, Greece and Cuba.

title: Eight Gifts for Athletic Newlyweds
description: Some reasonably priced gifts for keeping fit after the wedding.

title: Purim! The Musical
description: Every year, the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue on West 68th Street in Manhattan holds a special celebration for Purim, the Jewish holiday that commemorates the saving of the ancient Jews of Persia from mass slaughter by Haman the Agagite.

title: How Anna Kaiser, Fitness Entrepreneur, Spends Her Sundays
description: Anna Kaisers work schedule is nothing short of grueling. Ms. Kaiser, the founder and chief executive of AKT, a group of dance-based boutique fitness studios, said she puts in 14-hour days Monday through Saturday, shuttling between her four locations  two in Manhattan, one in the Hamptons and one in New Canaan, Conn.  to teach classes. She says she also manages to fit in private sessions with celebrity clients like the singer Shakira and duties as a host of an ABC reality series, My Diet Is Better Than Yours. She takes Sundays off. Ms. Kaiser, 36, lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Dr. Carlos K. Wesley, 41, a hair restoration surgeon, and their miniature Australian shepherd, Harlie.

title: Barneys Celebrates Downtown Opening With Leather Jacket Charity
description: Its a huge, full-circle moment, Mark Lee, the chief executive of Barneys New York, said on Thursday night, standing in the lobby of his sparkly new store in Chelsea, among handbags by Fendi, Givenchy and Maison Margiela.

title: What Do You Need to Do to Be a Supreme Court Justice?
description: IF someone could weaponize credentials  if a person could have a rsum so impressive that the mere sight of it could turn the tide of a war  that person would be Merrick B. Garland. Degrees from Harvard. A Supreme Court clerkship. A partnership in a multinational law firm. Multiple senior roles at the Department of Justice. Nineteen years on the second-most-powerful court in the country. Now hes just one very challenging confirmation vote away from his own seat on the Supreme Court.

title: Review: Roco Molina, Offering Dances of Wine and Glasses
description: The Spanish flamenco dancer Roco Molina held her foot over the wineglass, as if it were the sword of Damocles. And then she smashed the glass to bits.

title: The Nuclear Deal, Through Iranians Eyes
description: A photographer captures peoples views about the international agreement and the lifting of decade-old economic sanctions.

title: Calculate Your Economic Risk
description: TWO economic issues loom especially large in the United States today: widespread economic insecurity and soaring levels of income inequality. These are not just issues of interest to academics and policy makers; they are a prime concern of ordinary citizens. How much economic risk do I face in the future? you may wonder. How does my risk differ from that of others?

title: Against a Stacked Deck, Some Midmajors Do March On
description: DENVER  Josh Hagins celebrated his 22nd birthday on Thursday by giving every college basketball fan in America a gift: a tremendous upset on the first day of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Rooting for the Robber Barons, at Least on the Screen
description: This past week brought the announcement that the producer Ben Silverman, with partners, planned to create a television series based on Isnt That Rich, Richard Kirshenbaums column in The New York Observer examining the habits of the Upper East Side penthouse class. Writing from the perspective of someone living in a 5,000-square-foot duplex on Fifth Avenue, Mr. Kirshenbaum, an advertising executive, isnt agitating for upheaval. Voices quoted in his columns deliver lines like It isnt a Woody Allen movie anymore, its Moscow on the Hudson, referring to New York in the age of Bill de Blasio, but the voices belong to people Mr. Kirshenbaum is working out with, in private gyms, in even more fantastical apartments.

title: Bill Cunningham | Ups and Downs
description: Theres been a roller-coaster effect as fashion has soared between winter and spring from early February to last week. In response to the weather, women are nonchalantly tossing their coats and jackets over their shoulders. Colors are light. White faux fox collars add glamour. The new direction of fashion is not about shouting; its a whisper, an elegance redefined for a new era: navy blue coat, pinstripe trousers and, surprise, gold shoes (worn at 9 a.m.).

title: Why Were Not Making Plans for Coachella and Bonnaroo
description: Each year, shortly after New Years Day, the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival announces the lineup for its late-April dates. In response, the pop-music critics of The New York Times look at the names on the list  last years Grammy winners, makers of breakthrough records two years ago, slow-boiling Spotify stars whose rise has been deeply commented on by us and hundreds of others  and we rub our foreheads. A few weeks later comes Bonnaroos announcement, for early June, and we have still not sorted out Coachella.

title: Boulez and Harnoncourt, So Different, Yet More Alike Than They Realized
description: Its as if the postwar period itself had died. Within two months, Pierre Boulez and Nikolaus Harnoncourt, the two avant-gardists who more than anyone in the last half-century redefined classical music, were gone.

title: Review: Double Falsehood, and Just Maybe a Double Byline
description: Whether Shakespeare or someone else wrote it, you have to admire the prescience of Double Falsehood, at least as its being staged in a well-conceived production by the Letter of Marque Theater Company. Thanks largely to a scalding scene in the first half of the show, a central plotline seems as if it could be a commentary on the modern-day scourges of date rape and on-campus assaults.

title: Why Is Sean Penn Suing Lee Daniels?
description: Sean Penn is fighting. But not with his fists  repeat, not with his fists.

title: Debra Messing on the Talk Show Circuit
description: Even huddled under an umbrella Debra Messing was impossible to miss as she left The Late Show With Stephen Colbert the other week. There was the torrent of red hair. There was the explosive, infectious laugh.

title: Review: Philharmonic Goes Dada With Esa-Pekka Salonens Karawane
description: Not long into Esa-Pekka Salonens Karawane, a robust choral passage  the men sounding solemn, the women sinuous  begins to deflate just a bit. The sound starts to flatten into slight dissonance, as if the color is draining out of dozens of voices at once.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Review: Anais Mitchell Sings Her Own Work at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse
description: Call it a musical coup dtat.

title: Utah Ads Featuring Mitt Romney Target Donald Trump
description: The super PAC formed to stop Donald J. Trumps push for the Republican presidential nomination is spending $250,000 on television ads in Utah featuring Mitt Romney condemning the front-running candidate.

title: Orchestras Get in Tune With Modern Black-Tie
description: As the recent Academy Awards ceremony reminded us, fashion loves nothing better than making movie stars look perfect for that one night a year.

title: Review: A Program of Premieres by Paul Taylors American Modern Dance
description: Premieres have been popping forth from Paul Taylors American Modern Dance this week  with variable results. Wednesdays gala began with a piece (new to New York) by Mr. Taylor, Sullivaniana. Like many Taylor creations this century, it seemed like a skillful preliminary sketch of something this master didnt have the energy to turn into an interesting dance. It also looked neither American nor like modern dance.

title: Review: Too Blondes, a Cabaret of Comic Confusion
description: Although theyre not related, the musical-comedy team Savannah & Chase, a.k.a. Savannah Brown and Chase ODonnell, might be described as the Smothers Sisters. Too Blondes, their goofy, effervescent show at the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening, began with the kind of comedic confusion that used to be a running joke in Tom and Dick Smothers television variety show.

title: Review: Ideation, About an Office Teams Morally Disturbing New Project
description: They filter into the conference room, fatigued but triumphant, three guys just back from a consulting trip to Greece. Teasing one another, bantering with their boss, theyre a likable bunch  but only sort of. In the opening moments of Ideation, at 59E59 Theaters, an unsavory, even Mametian vibe underlies their swagger.

title: Another Gallery Is Raided in Antiquities Case
description: In their fifth raid in a week focusing on South Asian antiquities they say were looted, investigators have seized three items from a leader in the field, the Nancy Wiener Gallery of Manhattan.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: European Union, Salah Abdeslam, Merrick Garland
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Senator Grassleys Letter to the Wounded Warrior Project
description: In a March 18 letter, Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, asked Anthony Odierno of the Wounded Warrior Project for information concerning reports of lavish spending at the organization.

title: Senator Wants Data on Wounded Warrior Project, a Charity Under Fire
description: A week after the top executives of the Wounded Warrior Project were fired amid accusations of lavish spending, an influential senator on a committee that oversees nonprofit organizations is asking for a detailed accounting by the countrys largest veterans charity.

title: If John Kasichs Go-To Line Seems Familiar, Theres a Reason
description: With one catchy line, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has found a way to try to set himself apart from his more combative rivals.

title: A Mix of Beer, Bragging Rights and Horse Races at the Cheltenham Festival
description: PRESTBURY PARK, England  This is the place where horse stories become myths and the humans around them become legends. It is where horses glide over this soft ground, soaring over undulating hills as if they were big waves before taking flight over hurdles and steeplechase fences.

title: Presidential Candidates Woo Arizona Voters on Immigration
description: PHOENIX  When Donald J. Trump campaigns in Arizona, he talks up the endorsements he has received from Jan Brewer, the former governor who signed some of the nations toughest immigration laws, and Sheriff Joe Arpaio, whose aggressive pursuit of illegal immigrants has prompted discrimination charges by the Justice Department.

title: Evening Hours | Dance Performances and Art
description: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.

title: SoundCloud Signs Licensing Deal With Sony
description: SoundClouds tug of war with the music industry may finally be over.

title: Elliot Gant, Marketer of the Button-Down Shirt, Dies at 89
description: Linguists cant precisely pinpoint when button-down was redefined from cutting-edge collegiate to uniformly conformist, but the marketing expertise of the Gantmacher brothers of Brooklyn probably had something to do with it.

title: Merrick Garland Often Deferred to Government in Guantnamo Cases
description: WASHINGTON  After a judge ordered a Guantnamo Bay prisoner freed because the evidence that he was a Qaeda member was too thin, the government appealed the ruling to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. But as the detainees lawyers prepared to argue the case in January 2011, they had reason to hope that they might prevail again.

title: Spring May Start With Snow in New York Region
description: New Yorkers may be clamoring for spring, but the city could still get one more gust of winter.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Middle Tennessee State Sets Tone on a Day of Upsets
description: The odds looked strong for Michigan State  not just to make it past the first weekend of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, but to roll on to the Final Four, the coveted perch Coach Tom Izzo has practically transformed into his home away from home.

title: Hulk Hogan Awarded $115 Million in Privacy Suit Against Gawker
description: The retired wrestler Hulk Hogan was awarded $115 million in damages on Friday by a Florida jury in an invasion of privacy case against Gawker.com over its publication of a sex tape  an astounding figure that tops the $100 million he had asked for, that will probably grow before the trial concludes, and that could send a cautionary signal to online publishers despite the likelihood of an appeal by Gawker.

title: For Adam LaRoche, Blood Proves Thicker Than Infield Dirt
description: The first thing you noticed, upon entering the clubhouse of the Chicago White Sox in Glendale, Ariz., this spring training, was the jersey hanging in the corner stall. It looked just like all the others and was given the same prominence, but it was much smaller. Its owner, Drake LaRoche, No. 25, is only 14 years old. His father, Adam, was the White Sox designated hitter.

title: Bernie Sanders Forges Ahead With Jabs at Donald Trump
description: Undeterred by questions of delegate math or political momentum, Senator Bernie Sanders brushed off suggestions on Friday that his campaign had no way forward and forcefully made the case that he was the Democratic candidate better suited to defeat Donald J. Trump in a general election.

title: U.S. Steps Up Airstrikes Against ISIS After It Gains Territory in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The United States has significantly intensified its bombing campaign in Afghanistan in the past two months as part of President Obamas widening war against the Islamic State militants who have seized territory outside of Iraq and Syria, according to senior military commanders.

title: Yankees Starlin Castro Is Seeking New Walk-Up Song, and Other Hits
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Dread had given way to resignation on a late October night at Wrigley Field. The Chicago Cubs, already trailing the Mets by three games to none in the National League Championship Series, were down by four runs before they even came to bat. By the bottom of the sixth, with the Cubs trailing, 6-1, the capacity crowd was glum, preparing for the inevitable.

title: Jets Say Signing Ryan Fitzpatrick, Not Robert Griffin III, Is Still Focus
description: Jets General Manager Mike Maccagnan played down Robert Griffin IIIs recent two-day visit and used a conference call with reporters on Friday to repeatedly stress the teams desire to re-sign the free-agent quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick.

title: Business Executive From China Is Charged in U.N. Bribery Case
description: The broad United Nations corruption investigation that swept up a former president of the General Assembly expanded on Friday, as federal prosecutors charged a Chinese-born executive with paying at least $500,000 in bribes to buy diplomatic positions with the government of Antigua for her husband and another man.

title: Accusations of Sexism and Racism Shake Ad Agency and Industry
description: On Thursday afternoon at J. Walter Thompsons headquarters on Lexington Avenue in New York, the departing chief executive, Gustavo Martinez, handed the reins of the storied advertising agency to his successor, Tamara Ingram.

title: In Monthslong Hunt for Salah Abdeslam, Missed Chances and High Alerts
description: The prolonged search for Mr. Abdeslam, believed to have driven the car that carried terrorists to Paris, generated intense criticism of Belgian authorities.

title: Historic Win by Hawaii Puts an End to a Trying Week for California
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  As Cuonzo Martin paced the sideline, watching his best player get into foul trouble and his team play sloppy basketball, he kept reaching for a gold and blue towel. Every few plays, Martin, the California coach, would wipe his brow, dry his hands and clench the towel as his anger took hold.

title: Fox News Slams Donald Trump for Sick Obsession With Megyn Kelly
description: Donald J. Trump again turned his Twitter vitriol toward an old foe this week: Megyn Kelly, the Fox News anchor and frequent target of his social media ire. On Friday, the network said it had had enough.

title: Joe Santos, a Mainstay of The Rockford Files, Dies at 84
description: Joe Santos, a sturdily built, unpretentious character actor who had a memorable role as the overworked detective Dennis Becker on the popular 1970s drama The Rockford Files, died on Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 84.

title: Figure in Benghazi Inquiry Alters Suit on Firing
description: WASHINGTON  A former Republican staff member on the House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, has dropped allegations in a lawsuit that he had been dismissed in part because he objected to the panels focus on former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

title: And Theyre Off
description: The Cheltenham Festival usually falls around St. Patricks Day and the Irish come in force to root for their horses against their English rivals.

title: Halfcourt Heave Lifts Northern Iowa
description: Paul Jesperson banked in a halfcourt shot at the buzzer to give 11th-seeded Northern Iowa a win over sixth-seeded Texas on Friday night in a West Region first-round game in Oklahoma City.

title: Amid Scandals, Senior Judge in Brazil Suspends Ex-Presidents Cabinet Nomination
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A justice on Brazils highest court on Friday night suspended the nomination of the countrys former president to a cabinet post in President Dilma Rousseffs government, the latest twist in a political crisis that has Latin Americas largest country on edge.

title: 50 Ways to Leave The Donald
description: Rational Republicans are desperately trying to figure out a way to get rid of Donald Trump. Their desperation is so great, youd expect someone to release a herd of crocodiles on Mar-a-Lago.

title: Michigan State, Poised for a Deep Run, Crashes Into Middle Tennessee
description: ST. LOUIS  When did Jaqawn Raymond, Middle Tennessee States starting point guard, feel certain that his 15th-seeded Blue Raiders would defeat No. 2-seeded Michigan State and pull off one of the biggest upsets in N.C.A.A. tournament history?

title: Killing of Italian Student, Giulio Regeni, Puts Focus on Egypts Stability
description: CAIRO  Ever since the brutalized body of a 28-year-old Italian student, Giulio Regeni, was discovered on the  side of a road on Feb. 2, lurid theories have abounded about who, or what, was responsible for his death.

title: Kathryn Reed Altman, Film Directors Widow and Archivist, Dies at 91
description: Kathryn Reed Altman, who helped safeguard and enhance the artistic legacy of her husband, the film director Robert Altman, died on March 9 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 91.

title: Cholera Deaths in Haiti Could Far Exceed Official Count
description: Deaths from the cholera epidemic that ravaged Haiti after the 2010 earthquake could be much higher than the 9,200 officially tallied so far because of underreporting during the initial outbreak, a new study suggests.

title: Prince Announces Coming Memoir at Performance
description: Leave it to Prince to announce his new memoir with a last-minute invitation-only performance at a Manhattan nightclub.

title: Obamacares Birth-Control Exemption Still Tramples on Rights
description: TWENTY-EIGHT years ago, I vowed to consecrate my life to living with, loving and caring for the elderly poor. Since then, I have been blessed to live in a community of women who seek to treat every elderly person in our care with love and respect  as if we were caring for Christ himself.

title: The Ups and Downs of the Bradford Pear
description: Mount Rainier, Md.  SPRING arrives on Sunday, and in the nations capital, that means a certain tree is bursting in radiant cream-colored flowers.

title: Foster Father Charged With Sexually Abusing 5 Boys on Long Island
description: A longtime foster father on Long Island has been charged with sexually abusing five boys, all of them his adopted sons, in a case where the authorities suspect there are many more victims.

title: Inching Toward Safer Homeless Shelters
description: No doubt about it: The crime statistics in New York City look rosy. But Mayor Bill de Blasio is not in a good position to boast  not when people are living on the streets and subways because they dont want to be robbed, stabbed, beaten or killed in homeless shelters.

title: Brazils Political Crisis Deepens
description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil is fighting for political survival as calls for her impeachment grow louder amid a widening corruption investigation and a tanking economy.

title: What Planned Parenthood Really Does
description: AKRON, Ohio  A nurse took Tiara Thurmans blood pressure at the Planned Parenthood health center in Akron. Ms. Thurman, 24, was at the clinic this week to get Depo-Provera, an injectable form of birth control that works for three months. The nurse asked Ms. Thurman about her family history, allergies and history of surgeries and pregnancy  she has a daughter, now 2. The nurse offered Ms. Thurman free condoms.

title: Extremely Green
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE This was an excellent, juicy puzzle by a master of Saturdays, Byron Walden. There was just enough for me to sink my teeth into before getting stumped, and the head-scratchers were conceived so well that finally finishing was true gratification.

title: Schenn Brothers Have Been on Hot Streaks Since Being Separated by Trade
description: VOORHEES, N.J.  Brayden Schenns teammate, roommate, summer workout partner and regular dinner companion left town for good Jan. 6, headed on a plane to Los Angeles. That person also happened to be Schenns older brother, Luke.

title: Sergio Arellano Stark, Chilean General Who Led Death Squad, Dies at 94
description: Sergio Arellano Stark, a Chilean general whose airborne Caravan of Death murdered opponents of the 1973 coup that deposed Chiles democratically elected president, Salvador Allende, died on March 9 in Santiago de Chile. He was 94.

title: Upsets From Coast to Coast
description: The second full day of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament was full of unexpected victories.

title: Larry Drake, Lovable Clerk on L.A. Law, Dies at 67
description: Larry Drake, a longtime actor best known for his Emmy-winning role as a developmentally disabled character on the television drama L.A. Law, was found dead on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 67.

title: Prominent Tory Quits British Cabinet Over Welfare Cuts
description: LONDON  A former leader of Britains Conservative Party, Iain Duncan Smith, resigned from the cabinet on Friday over proposed cuts to welfare payments, dealing a significant and unexpected blow to Prime Minister David Cameron.

title: Judge Revokes Bail for Owen Labrie, Man Convicted in Senior Salute Case
description: Owen Labrie, the New England prep school graduate who was free on bail after an October conviction for having sex with a minor in a ritual called senior salute, was jailed on Friday after a judge ruled that he had violated his court-imposed curfew.

title: David Wright Seems Unbothered by Spine in First Game Back
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With a stocked pitching staff and a solid lineup, the Mets are poised to build on their success last year.

title: FlyDubai Plane Crashes at Russian Airport, Killing Over 60
description: MOSCOW  A Boeing 737-800 from Dubai with 62 people aboard crashed early Saturday during a landing attempt at the airport in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, Russian officials said.

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: Quentin Tarantinos latest talky, bloody foray into historical genre movies, The Hateful Eight, arrives online. And Dateline reports on the death of a woman found in her mansion.

title: Corrections: March 19, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Were not just at the center of the immigration discussion. The border is our backyard. We live the challenges of immigration every single day.

title: Serena Williams Closer to Making Her Indian Wells Return Triumphant
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Fifteen years after she last won here in front of a virulently hostile crowd, Serena Williams booked a spot in the final of the BNP Paribas Open, beating Agnieszka Radwanska, 6-4, 7-6 (1), in a semifinal match Friday evening.

title: Obama Wins Either Way: Our Best Comments of the Week
description: Here are the 10 comments of the week on the digital platforms of The New York Times, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Namaste and I Do
description: Brett Barakett and Meaghan Jarensky were married at their home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Fighting a Fake Dating Profile, Together
description: Brett Barakett and Meaghan Jarensky didnt find each other on a dating site, but a posting on Match.com  a blatantly counterfeit one  nearly broke them up.

title: Donald Trump on Mitt Romney: Are You Sure Hes a Mormon?
description: Speaking in Salt Lake City  home to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints headquarters  Donald J. Trump questioned Mitt Romneys membership in the faith on Friday, asking a crowd at a rally, Are you sure hes a Mormon?

title: What Happens When Millennials Run the Workplace?
description: Joel Pavelski, 27, isnt the first person who has lied to his boss to scam some time off work.

title: Teenage Drivers? Be Very Afraid
description: Spend enough time having parenting conversations, as Ive done personally and professionally for the last dozen years, and certain patterns emerge. In nine out of 10 cases, if youre talking about highly motivated parents, the message to Mom and Dad is: back off, chill out, park the helicopter.

title: Fighting Macular Degeneration
description: Q. Are there any new treatments in the pipeline for age-related macular degeneration?

title: A Mothers Death, a Daughters Life: Remembering Natalie Wood
description: LOS ANGELES  The home that Natasha Gregson Wagner shares with her husband, his sons and their daughter in Venice, a seaside neighborhood here, smells clean in a non-antiseptic way and, on a recent visit, faintly of the lilacs that rested in a vase on the kitchen countertop.

title: Get Ready, Internet. The Pope Has Joined Instagram.
description: In the three years since Pope Francis joined Twitter, he has attracted more than 25 million followers in nine languages. On Saturday, the pontiff added a new app to his social media mix: The pope joined Instagram.

description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the White House to an improvised border camp in Greece.

description: Donald Trump is about 550 delegates short of earning the 1,237 delegates necessary to win the Republican nomination.

title: Carrier Workers See Costs, Not Benefits, of Global Trade
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The fuzzy video, shot by a worker on the floor of a Carrier factory here in the American heartland last month, captured the raging national debate over trade and the future of the working class in 3 minutes 32 seconds.

title: A Little Variety
description: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Farhad and Mike Parse Virtual Reality Tech and the Apple Standoff
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Can I Break My Lease Over Subway Noise?
description: Noise Problems

title: Kirk Franklin Combines Faith and Fervor
description: Thank you Kirk for standing by me through all the noise. That was Kanye West on Twitter a few days ago, sharing his appreciation for Kirk Franklin, a pillar of the gospel music world for more than two decades who had worked on Ultralight Beam, the soaring opening number from Mr. Wests latest album, The Life of Pablo. Two top talents in collaboration  easy enough, right?

title: NBCSN Announcer Rebecca Lowe Faces a Hiatus
description: Seven weeks remain in an improbable Premier League season. Leicester City is in first place. Manchester United is in crisis. Chelsea, the defending champion, is adrift after an early-season collapse.

title: Wind Given as Possible Cause of Fatal Plane Crash in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A Boeing 737-800 from the United Arab Emirates with 62 people aboard crashed early Saturday while trying to land at the airport in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, Russian officials said.

description: ISTANBUL  A suicide bomber struck at the heart of Istanbuls most popular avenue on Saturday, killing at least four people, including two Americans, and wounding 36, officials said.

title: Jewelry for Everyday
description: On a typical weekend afternoon at Catbird  a cozy boutique in Brooklyns vibrant Williamsburg neighborhood  the store is filled with women in their 20s, 30s and 40s, many browsing through a selection of delicate jewelry. Especially popular: 14-carat gold rings, fashioned from thin stretches of hammered metal, chain links or tiny connected balls.

title: 7 Virtual Reality Highlights From the Game Developers Conference
description: One thing was made abundantly clear at this years Game Developers Conference in San Francisco: Virtual reality games can take players virtually anywhere they can dream up.

title: Variety: An Antecedent Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  In 2016, were still finding out about Earths history and the development of humanity. Its impressive and amazing how linguists and paleoanthropologists can create a rich picture of life, including sounds and emotions, from fossils and artifacts. For anyone interested in the history of words and language, this was a passage that was fun to discover.

title: Puerto Rico Braces for Its Own Zika Epidemic
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  On an inexorable march across the hemisphere, the Zika virus has begun spreading through Puerto Rico, now the United States front line in a looming epidemic.

title: Could Term Limits Ease Fights Over Supreme Court Nominees?
Will Trump Be Dumped?
description: WASHINGTON  MOST people would be upset to be at the center of an agitated national debate about whether they were more like Hitler, Mussolini, Idi Amin, George Wallace or a Marvel villain.

title: Migrants Lament as Deal With Turkey Closes Door to Europe
description: IZMIR, Turkey  Smoking cigarettes and huddling against the midnight chill, a group of Syrian men sat outside a mosque waiting for a smugglers call. It was their last chance, they said, to reach Europe.

title: Harold Ickes, Mentor to Mayor Bill de Blasio, Builds Lobbying Victories
description: When New York City banned whole milk from public schools in 2006, seeking to reduce obesity and improve students health, a trade group for the American dairy industry hired a well-connected Washington lobbyist to fight back.

title: A Bitter Pill for Tennessee in Its Rivalry With UConn
description: The gulf in the once-prominent rivalry between Connecticut and Tennessee, the most storied programs in Division I womens college basketball, has never been wider. But right in the heart of Lady Vols country, at least one player of state renown is all in on the Huskies bid for an unprecedented fourth consecutive Division I national title.

title: Foreign to Many, the Language of College Basketball Has Its Fluent Speakers
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The patois of college basketball gives the game some of its unique flavor in the film room or on the court during the tedium of daily practice.

title: Selling High-End Socks by Giving Them Away
description: David Heath, a 32-year-old entrepreneur wearing customized black and pink Nikes, hovered near the lunch line at the Bowery Mission, one of New Yorks oldest homeless shelters.

description: On the waterfront

description: If this were anything like a normal year, the Republicans would be favored to take the White House. That, at least, is what Ray Fairs economic model has been saying consistently since November 2014.

title: Lucy Jones: Saving Lives on Fault Lines
description: Lucy Jones, 61, is the science adviser for risk reduction at the United States Geological Survey in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Paris Suspect Claims He Backed Out of Stadium Bombing, Prosecutor Says
description: BRUSSELS  Salah Abdeslam, believed to be the only direct participant in the November attacks in Paris who is still alive, told investigators on Saturday after being captured a day earlier that he wanted to detonate his suicide vest at the Stade de France soccer stadium on the night of the attacks but backed out, said the lead terrorism prosecutor in France.

title: A Peek Inside Harry Potters New Hollywood World
description: As Universal prepares to open a new Harry Potter attraction in California, it has learned from the long lines and other issues it encountered in Florida.

title: Charlotte Hornets, a Team Created in 2004, Set Its Wins Record in 1997
description: With the way the Charlotte Hornets have been playing recently, it may finally be time to retire the Crying Jordan meme. While the Internets Photoshop enthusiasts will undoubtedly be sad at no longer eliciting easy laughs by replacing the head in any photo with Michael Jordans tear-strewn face from his Hall of Fame acceptance speech in 2009, the fact that the meaning behind the original meme may no longer be valid takes away some of its humor.

title: Privacy and the iPhone
description: Readers discuss the security issues raised in the clash between Apple and the government.

title: Profiles in Paralysis
description: WHEN an old order is in crisis, something distinctive happens to the men who lead it.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Transparency in the Drone Wars
description: The White House is expected next month to disclose how many combatants and noncombatants government officials believe have been killed in drone strikes outside declared war zones. The Obama administration will bill this as an effort to peel back a layer of secrecy on a controversial counterterrorism program that has long been dogged by questions about its morality and legality. That will be too little, too late.

title: Hollywoods Fake Version of Nina Simone
description: The jazz artist Nina Simone was intimately familiar with the scorn that this society heaps upon dark-skinned black women. The world she was born into in the 1930s told her in every possible way that ebony skin, a broad nose and full lips offended Eurocentric standards of beauty and made women of her complexion unworthy of admiration.

title: Life Among the Ruins
description: NEXT month, the Temple of Baal will come to Times Square. Reproductions of the 50-foot arch that formed the temples entrance are to be installed in New York and in London, a tribute to the 2,000-year-old structure that the Islamic State destroyed last year in the Syrian town of Palmyra. The groups rampage through Palmyra, a city that reached its peak in the second and third century A.D., enraged the world, spurring scholars and conservationists into action. Numerous nongovernmental organizations are now cataloging and mapping damaged cultural heritage sites in the region.

title: Sarah Weiner
description: Sarah Weiner is a co-founder of Seedling Projects, a nonprofit organization based in San Francisco, which promotes sustainable food through events like its annual Good Food Awards.

title: Building a Better Anonymouse Trap
description: THE TIMES has a new way to handle information supplied by people who dont want to be identified by name  also known as anonymous sources, or jocularly, because they are omnipresent and hard to control, as anonymice.

title: Poisoned Water in Newark Schools
description: Newark Public Schools recently acknowledged that the water at its schools has contained high levels of lead for years. This is shocking but, sadly, not surprising given the neglect of public schools, especially those in poor communities, by Congress and state governments.

title: The Worlds Modern-Day Lepers: Women With Fistulas
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  ONE of the worst things that can happen to a woman or girl around the world is a fistula, an internal injury caused by childbirth (or occasionally by rape) that leaves her incontinent, humiliated and sometimes stinking.

title: When Did Porn Become Sex Ed?
description: THE other day, I got an email from a 21-year-old college senior about sex  or perhaps more correctly, about how ill equipped she was to talk about sex. The abstinence-only curriculum in her middle and high schools had taught her little more than dont, and shed told me that although her otherwise liberal parents would have been willing to answer any questions, it was pretty clear the topic made them even more uncomfortable than it made her.

title: The Hidden Price of Mindfulness Inc.
description: THE other morning, I woke up and brewed a cup of Mindful Lotus tea ($6 for 20 bags). On the subway, I loaded the Headspace app on my iPhone and followed a guided mindfulness exercise ($13 a month for premium content). Later in the day, I dropped by Mndfl, a meditation studio in Greenwich Village ($20 for a 45-minute class).

title: Dying, With Nothing to Say
description: MY father died of a heart attack. He was with my mother, on his way home from a concert and dinner with friends, and he collapsed in the marble lobby of their building. There was no preparation. There were no last conversations.

title: How a Fitbit May Make You a Bit Fit
description: Toronto  THE ultracompact, platform-agnostic, user-configurable mobile fitness device that Dr. Michael Joyner showed off at a recent sports technology conference caused a stir. The attendees had gathered to ponder the future of high-tech performance enhancement.

title: All Things Come to an End. Even My 2001 Saturn.
description: Urbana, Ill.  WHEN you drive an old and shabby car, as I do, you try to make the best of it. Theres even a kind of reverse bragging involved: just how old, how shabby, how gruesomely it can shed parts and systems and still get you from place to place. There are cars in far worse shape than yours on the road. So you tell yourself. The ones whose mileage equals a trip to the moon and halfway back, the ones that need to be push-started every time, the ones lacking structural integrity in their roofs or floorboards.

title: Owning Up to Torture
description: IN March 2004, at Forward Operating Base St. Mere outside Falluja, Iraq, I was walking home from work. Ferdinand Ibabao, my close friend and fellow contractor, was walking with me. It had been a long day of interrogations, so we were looking forward to checking emails, and hearing about what our families were up to back home.

title: The Man the Founders Feared
description: I THINK youd have riots. So said Donald J. Trump last week, when he was asked by CNN what he thought would happen if he arrived at the Republican Convention this summer a few delegates short of the 1,237 needed to win outright and didnt set forth from Cleveland as the partys nominee.

title: Republican Leaders Map a Strategy to Derail Donald Trump
description: Republican leaders adamantly opposed to Donald J. Trumps candidacy are preparing a 100-day campaign to deny him the presidential nomination, starting with an aggressive battle in Wisconsins April 5 primary and extending into the summer, with a delegate-by-delegate lobbying effort that would cast Mr. Trump as a calamitous choice for the general election.

title: TV Trailer Hitches to Golden States Star
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In a dim corridor not far from the court at Oracle Arena, a small team of technicians crammed into a small, space-age trailer. Tom Adza took his usual seat behind a bank of monitors and put on a headset.

description: The rise of the mighty Golden State Warriors is being documented in the unlikeliest of places: a cramped television trailer deep within Oaklands Oracle Arena.

title: A Road Map for Maria Sharapova, but One That Goes Only So Far
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  After testing positive for the banned substance meldonium, Maria Sharapova does not need to look hard for a glimpse of the road ahead.

title: Emirates Rise Is Faced With Growing Threats
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  In international soccer, the United Arab Emirates are looking good. The national team finished third at the 2015 Asian Cup continental tournament, and it is stocked with the countrys golden generation of players. The team has a real chance to qualify for the 2018 World Cup.

title: C. C. Sabathias Struggles May Open Spot for Ivan Nova in the Starting Rotation
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Dellin Betances, who has been to the All-Star Game in each of his first two seasons, no longer comes to spring training with the same intensity  or anxiety  that he did several years ago. Betances is simply trying to prepare for the start of the season, not win a job.

title: Anti-Trump Protesters Block Road in Arizona and Clash With Police in New York
description: Protesters in Arizona blocked a major road leading to a Donald J. Trump rally on Saturday outside Phoenix, while anti-Trump demonstrators in New York clashed with the police on a march toward Trump Tower.

title: Kansas Gives Connecticut Coach His First Loss in the Tournament

description: Legal scholars were as startled as anyone by the scale of the damages awarded by a Florida jury on Friday to the retired professional wrestler known as Hulk Hogan in his suit against Gawker.com for posting a sex tape.

title: Once the Yankees Future, a Big Three Settle for the Present
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  Joba Chamberlain will soon get another World Series ring. He pitched in six games last September for the Kansas City Royals, entering each with his team trailing, saving the bullpen for others. The Royals, his third organization of the season, went on to beat the Mets for the championship.

title: Capitals Braden Holtby Finds a Kindred Spirit in His Goaltender Coach
description: When Mitch Korn became the coach of the Washington Capitals goaltenders in June 2014, he set about familiarizing himself with his players.

title: Husband, Father and Champion Make a Lot to Balance
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  At his introductory news conference in Denver on Monday, the N.F.L. quarterback Mark Sanchez made a statement meant to underscore his commitment to winning. Im not married, he said. I dont have a girlfriend. I dont have kids. I just want to play ball.

title: Gallup Finds Concerns Rising Over Global Warming and Nuclear Energy Solution
description: Comments are off; see the production note at the end of this post.

title: At 68, a Condiment King Finally Gets a Taste of Mets Spring Training

title: Certain Balloons
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE Solving this seemed like a lengthy endeavor to me, though a pleasant one  not only were there three steps to finish it completely, but the grid was awfully dense. Fortunately most of the kajillion clues were clean and clear, with enough originality thrown in to keep my interest up.

description: After tearing up millions of brackets on Thursday and Friday, underdogs in this years N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament flooded the weekend. title: U.S. Marine Killed by Islamic State Rocket Attack in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  A United States Marine was killed on Saturday after a base in northern Iraq came under attack from Islamic State fighters, a Pentagon official said. It was the second death of an American service member in combat since the United States first struck the militant group in 2014.

title: Man Tied to Hindu Vigilante Group Among 5 Held in Deaths of 2 Muslims
description: NEW DELHI  A member of a Hindu vigilante group organized to protect cows was among five men arrested on Saturday in connection with the murder of two Muslim cattle traders, who were beaten and then hanged from a tree, the police said.

description: SAN SEBASTIN, Spain  Still relatively young chefs when they went to France 40 years ago, Juan Mari Arzak and Pedro Subijana were determined not only to learn, but also to lift Basque cooking and then spread their know-how.

description: READING, N.Y.  They came here to get arrested.

title: Sanctions Eased, Iran Sends Black Market a Strategic Warning
description: TEHRAN  The pastry shop, tucked away in an affluent west Tehran neighborhood and selling Disney-themed cakes and party hats, is not particularly notable except for one thing: It is owned and operated by Irans powerful Ministry of Petroleum.

title: In Louisiana, the Poor Lack Legal Defense
description: ABBEVILLE, La.  It was arraignment morning at the Vermilion Parish courthouse, the monthly catalog of bad decisions, hot tempers, hard hearts and hard luck. Natasha George, who until recently was one of 10 lawyers defending the poor of the parish, stood before the full gallery of defendants.

title: Colombian Children Pay High Price Amid Peace Talks, U.N. Says
description: COLOMBIA  About a quarter-million children in Colombia have been displaced by fighting in the past three years of peace negotiations between the government and the countrys leading guerrilla group, the United Nations said in a report released Saturday.

title: A View of ISISs Evolution in New Details of Paris Attacks
description: Investigators found crates worth of disposable cellphones. All around Paris, they found traces of improved bomb-making materials. And they began piecing together a multilayered terrorist attack that evaded detection until much too late.

title: John Kasich Is Presidential, Ad Says, Implying His Rivals Are Decidedly Not
description: The party of Lincoln, Eisenhower and Reagan, thrown into turmoil by childish insults and riotous campaign rallies. Whats happened? asks a voice with the gruffness of a man old enough to remember at least two of those lionized leaders.

title: El Nio Upsets Seasons and Upends Lives Worldwide
description: In rural villages in Africa and Asia, and in urban neighborhoods in South America, millions of lives have been disrupted by weather linked to the strongest El Nio in a generation.

title: After Trailing Duke by 27, Yale Musters a Last Thrill on Its Way Out
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  At some point in every tournament game, the outcome becomes obvious and the focus for the loser invariably turns to the journey. Yale being Yale, that moment was bound to come sooner rather than later in the N.C.A.A. tournament, especially with a second-round matchup Saturday against Duke at Dunkin Donuts Center.

title: Forced to Renew an Old Rivalry With Kentucky, Indiana Prevails
description: DES MOINES  So why, exactly, dont these teams schedule each other anymore?

title: Jason Day Is Feeling the Heat as He Pursues a Wire-to-Wire Victory

Anyone who wandered in out of the rain to catch the tail end of Jason Days news conference on Saturday might have thought he was describing having to drive home in clothes that were soaked to his skin. Days discomfort was a theme he kept returning to, but it had nothing to do with the awful weather that turned Bay Hill Golf Club into a sodden sponge in the afternoon. He was forecasting an uncomfortable 24 hours because of his standing as the tournaments 54-hole leader.

title: When Middle Tennessee Won, Syracuses Coaches Were Ready
description: ST. LOUIS  After Syracuse beat Dayton, 70-51, on Friday, several of the Oranges coaches watched the Midwest Region game between No. 15-seeded Middle Tennessee State and No. 2-seeded Michigan State at Scottrade Center. They knew they would be playing the winner.

title: American Firm, Starwood, Signs Deal to Manage Hotels in Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY  Starwood Hotels and Resorts is set become the first American hospitality chain to run hotels in Cuba in more than half a century, signaling the return of American companies to the Cuban travel market as the island gears up to receive a surge in visits from the United States.

description: Ladies, this years fragrance is DEET.

description: NEW YORK

title: Well-Traveled Serb Finds a Home in Hawaii
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Drago Jankovic was working Saturday morning in Canada, driving his truck, when he pulled out his phone and recorded a video for his son Stefan, who a day earlier helped Hawaii defeat No. 4-seeded California in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Drago was so full of pride, he sang a Hawaiian song and shouted as he drove.

title: For Wisconsins Scorekeeper, Most Impressive Number Is His Age: 83
description: ST. LOUIS  Tom Landry coached the Dallas Cowboys for 29 seasons. Jim Boeheim is in his 40th year leading Syracuse. Connie Mack managed the Philadelphia Athletics for a half-century.

description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Even for the sports best, any success against top-ranked Novak Djokovic  however relative  must be appreciated.

description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Virginia added to an unconventional N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament on Saturday night, but not in the manner of the upset stories that have ruled the first four days. The Cavaliers, regarded as a ferocious defensive team, turned themselves into an offensive locomotive against Butler.

title: Protester Punched and Kicked at Donald Trump Rally in Tucson
description: Donald J. Trumps second rally in Arizona on Saturday was studded with repeated interruptions from protesters, along with an incident in which a member of the crowd punched and kicked a protester and another that involved Mr. Trumps campaign manager.

Muncie, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion , officiated at Race and Religious, an event space in New Orleans.

description: Adam Jonathan Plotkin, the son of Mari Plotkin and Dr. David Plotkin of Short Hills, N.J., is to be married March 20 to Adam Bernard Abrahams, a son of Sheila Abrahams and Alan Abrahams of Issaquah, Wash. description: Allison Patterson Harris and Amir Shawn Fairdosi are to be married March 20 at the James A. Michener Art Museum in Doylestown, Pa. The Rev. Geoffrey A. Black, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to officiate.

title: Spurs Add to Streak as Warriors Fall to 62-7
description: SAN ANTONIO  The Golden State Warriors have been a history-making machine this season, overshadowing nearly every team that tries to impede their progress. The San Antonio Spurs, though, are assembling a magical season of their own, and they stifled the Warriors, 87-79, on Saturday night at AT&T Center to make a little history of their own.

title: Trump Didnt Put the Con in Conservatism
description: So, Im in a time zone far, far away  and also still shaky, although Im finally managing to hold down some food.
